Here, what</b> is the ruling? <b>He said to him: Were all of them woven in the same</b> act of <b>weaving?</b> Are there no distinctions between different cases? <b>Rather, where it is stated, it is stated, and where it is not stated, it is not stated,</b> and there is no comparison.
<b>Rav Mari said to Rav Pappa:</b> Does it constitute nakedness <b>if one’s</b> pubic <b>hair protruded from his garment?</b> Rav Pappa said <b>about him: A hair, a hair.</b> You are splitting hairs and being pedantic over trivialities.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak stated: An</b> exposed <b>handbreadth in a woman</b> constitutes <b>nakedness.</b> The Gemara asks: Regarding <b>which</b> <i>halakha</i> was this said? <b>If you say</b> that it comes to prohibit <b>looking at</b> an exposed handbreadth in <b>her, didn’t Rav Sheshet say: Why did the verse enumerate</b> “anklets and bracelets, rings, earrings and girdles” (Numbers 31:50), <b>jewelry that is</b> worn <b>externally,</b> over her clothing, e.g., bracelets, <b>together with jewelry</b> worn <b>internally,</b> beneath her clothing, near her nakedness, e.g., girdles? This was <b>to tell you: Anyone who gazes upon a woman’s little finger</b> is considered <b>as if he gazed upon her</b> naked <b>genitals,</b> for if his intentions are impure, it makes no difference where he looks or how much is exposed; even less than a handbreadth.
<b>Rather,</b> it is referring even to <b>his wife, with regard to</b> the <b>recitation of <i>Shema</i>.</b> One may not recite <i>Shema</i> before an exposed handbreadth of his wife.
Along these lines, <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> Even <b>a woman’s</b> exposed <b>leg</b> is considered <b>nakedness, as it is stated: “Uncover the leg and pass through the rivers”</b> (Isaiah 47:2), <b>and it is written</b> in the following verse: <b>“Your nakedness shall be revealed and your shame shall be seen”</b> (Isaiah 47:3). <b>Shmuel</b> further <b>stated: A woman’s</b> singing <b>voice is</b> considered <b>nakedness,</b> which he derives from the praise accorded a woman’s voice, <b>as it is stated: “Sweet is your voice and your countenance is alluring”</b> (Song of Songs 2:14). Similarly, <b>Rav Sheshet stated:</b> Even <b>a woman’s hair is</b> considered <b>nakedness,</b> for it too is praised, <b>as it is written: “Your hair is like a flock of goats,</b> trailing down from Mount Gilead” (Song of Songs 4:1).
The Gemara resumes its discussion of phylacteries. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: I saw Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>hang his phylacteries.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one who hangs his phylacteries will have his life hang</b> in the balance.
Moreover, <b>the Symbolic Interpreters</b> of the Torah <b>said</b> that the verse: <b>“And your life shall hang in doubt before you [<i>minneged</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 28:66), that is the punishment of <b>one who hangs his phylacteries.</b>
The Gemara replies: This apparent contradiction <b>is not difficult, as this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which condemns one who hangs his phylacteries, refers to one who hangs them <b>by the strap,</b> allowing the leather boxes into which the parchment is placed to dangle in a deprecating way, which is certainly prohibited. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which relates that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would hang his phylacteries and that it is clearly permitted, refers to when one hangs them <b>from the box</b> with the straps dangling.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> another explanation instead: <b>There is no difference</b> whether he hangs the phylacteries from the <b>strap and there is no difference</b> whether he hangs the phylacteries from <b>the box;</b> both <b>are prohibited. And when Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>hung</b> his phylacteries, <b>he hung them in</b> their <b>pouch.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>to relate</b> that incident? The Gemara replies: <b>Lest you say</b> that phylacteries <b>would require placement</b> atop a surface, <b>as</b> is the custom with <b>a Torah scroll.</b> Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that this is unnecessary.
Since Rabbi Ḥanina related a story involving Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the Gemara cites another such story. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: I saw Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, while he was praying, <b>belch, yawn, sneeze, spit,</b>

Daf 24b

<b>and</b> if he was stung by a louse, he may <b>feel</b> for it and remove it <b>with his garment, but he would not wrap himself</b> in his prayer shawl if it fell during prayer. <b>And when he would yawn he would place his hand on his chin</b> so that his open mouth would not be visible.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who sounds his voice during his</b> <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer is among those of little faith,</b> as he seems to believe that the Lord cannot hear his prayer when it is uttered silently. <b>One who raises his voice during prayer is</b> considered to be <b>among the false prophets,</b> as they too were wont to cry out and shout to their gods.
Furthermore, one who <b>belches and yawns</b> while praying <b>is surely among the uncouth. One who sneezes during his prayer, for him it is a bad omen. And some say: It is clear that he is repulsive.</b> Also, <b>one who spits during prayer, it is tantamount to spitting in the face of the king.</b> In light of all this, how could Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi have done all that while praying?
The Gemara explains: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>one who belches and yawns, it is not difficult: Here,</b> in the case where Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi did so, <b>it was involuntary</b> and therefore permissible; <b>here,</b> where it is considered uncouth, is in a case where <b>it is deliberate.</b> However, the contradiction <b>between sneezing</b> in the case where Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi did so <b>and sneezing</b> where it is considered a bad omen <b>is difficult.</b>
The Gemara responds: The contradiction <b>between sneezing</b> in one case <b>and sneezing</b> in the other case <b>is also not difficult: Here,</b> in the case of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, it is referring to sneezing <b>from above,</b> his nose; <b>here,</b> where it is a bad omen, is referring to sneezing <b>from below,</b> flatulence. <b>As Rav Zeira said: In the school of Rav Hamnuna I absorbed this matter</b> in passing, <b>and it is equal</b> in significance <b>to all the rest of my learning: One who sneezes in the midst of prayer, it is a good omen for him. Just as</b> the sneeze soothes his irritation, <b>giving him pleasure below,</b> it is a sign that <b>they are similarly giving him pleasure above.</b> Since Rav Zeira sneezed often, he was extremely pleased to hear this.
<b>However,</b> The contradiction <b>between spitting</b> in the case where Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi did so <b>and spitting</b> where it is deemed tantamount to spitting in the face of the king <b>is difficult.</b> The Gemara replies: The contradiction <b>between spitting</b> in one case <b>and spitting</b> in the other case <b>is also not difficult,</b> as <b>it is possible</b> to resolve it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> as <b>Rav Yehuda said: One who was standing in prayer, and saliva happened</b> to accumulate in <b>his</b> mouth, <b>he absorbs it in his garment. And if it was a fine garment</b> and he does not want it to become sullied, <b>he may cover it up in his head covering.</b> That way, one is permitted to spit. The Gemara relates: <b>Ravina was standing behind Rav Ashi</b> during prayer when <b>saliva happened</b> to accumulate in <b>his</b> mouth, <b>so he discharged it behind him.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> And <b>does the Master not hold</b> in accordance with <b>that</b> statement of <b>Rav Yehuda, who said</b> that <b>one absorbs it in his head covering? He said to him: I am delicate,</b> and the mere knowledge that there is spittle in my head covering disturbs my prayer.
It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who sounds his voice during his</b> <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer is among those of little faith. Rav Huna said: This was only taught</b> in a case <b>where one is able to focus his heart</b> while praying silently, <b>but</b> if he <b>is unable to focus his heart</b> while praying <b>silently, he is permitted</b> to sound his voice. <b>This applies only to</b> one praying <b>alone,</b> but when he is praying <b>in a congregation</b> his voice <b>will come to disturb the congregation</b> and it is prohibited.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Abba was avoiding</b> being seen <b>by</b> his teacher <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> as Rabbi Abba <b>sought to ascend to Eretz Yisrael</b> and his teacher disapproved, <b>as Rav Yehuda said: Anyone who ascends from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael transgresses a positive commandment, as it is stated: “They shall be taken to Babylonia and there they shall remain until the day that I recall them, said the Lord”</b> (Jeremiah 27:22). Rabbi Abba did not want to discuss his desire to emigrate with Rav Yehuda. Nevertheless <b>he said: I will go and hear something from him at the hall</b> where the Sages <b>assemble,</b> without being seen, <b>and afterwards I will leave</b> Babylonia.
<b>He went and found the <i>tanna</i>,</b> who recites the tannaitic sources before the study hall, <b>reciting</b> the following <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Yehuda: One who was standing in prayer and sneezed</b> from below <b>waits until the odor dissipates and resumes praying. Some say: One who was standing in prayer when he felt the need to sneeze</b> from below, <b>retreats four cubits, sneezes, waits until the odor dissipates and resumes praying. And</b> before resuming his prayer, <b>he says: Master of the universe, You have formed us with many orifices and cavities; our disgrace and shame in life are clear and evident before You, as is our destiny with maggots and worms,</b> and so we should not be judged harshly. <b>And he resumes</b> his prayer <b>from where he stopped.</b>
Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: Had I only come</b> to the assembly of the Sages <b>to hear this teaching, it would have been sufficient for me.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> One who <b>was sleeping</b> unclothed, but was covered <b>with his garment, and he is unable to stick his head out</b> from under the garment <b>because of the cold,</b> may <b>form a barrier with his garment at his neck and recite <i>Shema</i></b> in bed. <b>And some say:</b> He must form a barrier with his garment <b>at his heart.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> shouldn’t he be prohibited from reciting <i>Shema</i> because <b>his heart sees</b> his <b>nakedness,</b> as there is no barrier between them? The Gemara responds: Indeed, the first <i>tanna</i> <b>holds that</b> when <b>one’s heart sees</b> his <b>nakedness, it is permitted</b> to recite <i>Shema</i>, and a barrier is only necessary to separate between his mouth and his nakedness.
<b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who was walking in alleyways filthy</b> with human excrement and he must recite <i>Shema</i>, <b>he places his hand over his mouth and recites <i>Shema</i>. Rav Ḥisda said to him: By God!</b> Even <b>if Rabbi Yoḥanan had said it to me</b> directly, <b>with his own mouth, I would not have obeyed him.</b>
<b>Some say</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One who was walking in alleyways filthy</b> with human excrement and he must recite <i>Shema</i>, <b>he places his hand over his mouth and recites <i>Shema</i>. Rav Ḥisda said to him: By God!</b> Even <b>if Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi had said it to me</b> directly, <b>with his own mouth, I would not have obeyed him.</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>Did Rav Huna</b> really <b>say that? Didn’t Rav Huna say: A Torah scholar is prohibited from standing in a place of filth, as he is unable to stand without contemplating Torah,</b> and uttering <i>Shema</i> orally is graver than mere contemplation. The Gemara responds: This <b>is not difficult; here,</b> Rav Huna prohibited contemplating Torah <b>in</b> a case where one is <b>standing</b> in a place of filth, while <b>here</b> he permitted to recite <i>Shema</i> <b>in</b> a case where one is <b>walking</b> through a place of filth.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> really <b>say that? Didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One is permitted to contemplate matters of Torah everywhere, except the bathhouse and the bathroom?</b> Consequently, it is prohibited to even contemplate Torah in a place of filth. <b>And if you say: Here, too,</b> there is a distinction between the two cases, <b>here,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan prohibited contemplating Torah <b>in</b> a case where one is <b>standing; here,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan permitted to recite <i>Shema</i> <b>in</b> a case where one is <b>walking, is that so? Wasn’t Rabbi Abbahu walking after Rabbi Yoḥanan and reciting <i>Shema</i>,</b> and <b>when he reached a filthy alleyway he fell silent</b> and stopped reciting <i>Shema</i>. When they emerged, Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: To where</b> in <i>Shema</i> <b>should I return</b> and resume reciting it? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: If you delayed</b> continuing <i>Shema</i> for an interval <b>sufficient to complete the entire</b> <i>Shema</i>, <b>return to the beginning</b> and recite it from there. From the fact that Rabbi Yoḥanan did not admonish him for interrupting his recitation, apparently he, too, prohibits reciting <i>Shema</i> while walking through a filthy alleyway.
The Gemara responds: This is not a proof, as <b>he says to him as follows: I do not hold</b> that one must interrupt the recitation of <i>Shema</i> in this case, but <b>for you, who holds</b> that one must, <b>if you delayed</b> <i>Shema</i> for an interval <b>sufficient to complete the entire</b> <i>Shema</i>, <b>return to the beginning</b> and recite it from there.
The Gemara cites tannaitic sources to corroborate both the lenient and the stringent opinions. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna, </b>and<b> it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda. It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna: One who was walking in filthy alleyways places his hand over his mouth and recites <i>Shema</i>. It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda: One who was walking in filthy alleyways may not recite <i>Shema</i>. Furthermore, if he was in the course of reciting</b> <i>Shema</i> when he reached a filthy alleyway, <b>he stops</b> his recitation at that point. 
The Gemara asks: If <b>one did not stop, what</b> is his status? <b>Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, said: Of him the verse says: “Moreover, I gave them statutes that were not good and laws by which they could not live”</b> (Ezekiel 20:25), as in this case following these statutes and laws led to sin, not to mitzva.
<b>Rav Asi said</b> that this is derived from the verse: <b>“Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity”</b> (Isaiah 5:18), meaning that this man brings sin upon himself for naught. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> it is derived <b>from here: “For he has shown contempt for the word of the Lord”</b> (Numbers 15:31), meaning that uttering God’s word in a place of filth shows contempt for the Lord.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if he stopped</b> his recitation, <b>what is his reward? Rabbi Abbahu said: Of him the verse says: “And it is through this matter that you will prolong your days”</b> (Deuteronomy 32:47), meaning that by being careful with one’s speech one merits longevity.
<b>Rav Huna said: One</b> whose <b>garment was tied around his waist,</b> even if he was bare above the waist, <b>is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>.</b> Indeed, <b>that</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> whose <b>garment</b> made <b>of cloth, of leather, of sack</b> or of any other material <b>was strapped around his waist, he is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>.</b>

Daf 25a

<b>However, for prayer,</b> one may not recite it <b>until he covers his heart,</b> because in prayer he addresses God directly and he must dress accordingly.
<b>And Rav Huna said: One</b> who <b>forgot and entered the bathroom while donning phylacteries places his hand on them until he finishes.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that he can do so <b>until he is finished? Rather, as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Until he finishes</b> discharging <b>the first mass</b> of feces, at which point he can step out and remove his phylacteries. The Gemara asks: <b>Let him stop immediately</b> when he realizes that he is donning phylacteries <b>and stand</b> and step out. The Gemara replies: He cannot do so <b>because of</b> the statement of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A mass</b> of feces <b>that is held back</b> without having been discharged <b>causes a person</b> to suffer <b>from dropsy [<i>hidrokan</i>], while a stream</b> of urine <b>that is held back causes a person</b> to suffer <b>from jaundice [<i>yerakon</i>].</b> Since there is potential danger, the Sages did not require him to step out.
<b>It was stated</b> that the Sages disagreed with regard to one who had <b>fecal matter on his skin or</b> whose <b>hand,</b> but not the rest of his body, <b>was placed inside the bathroom.</b> Under those circumstances, <b>Rav Huna said:</b> He is <b>permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>. Rav Ḥisda said: He is prohibited from reciting <i>Shema</i>. Rava said: What is the reason for Rav Huna’s</b> opinion? <b>As it is written: “Let every soul</b> [<b><i>neshama</i></b>] <b>praise the Lord; Halleluya”</b> (Psalms 150:6), which he interprets as “Let everything that has breath” [<i>neshima</i>]. As long as the mouth with which one recites praise is in a place of purity, the location of the other limbs of his body is irrelevant.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: He is prohibited from reciting <i>Shema</i>. What is the reason for Rav Ḥisda’s</b> opinion? <b>As it is written: “All of my bones shall say: Lord, who is like You”</b> (Psalms 35:10). Since this praise is undertaken with one’s entire body, he may not recite <i>Shema</i> even if just one limb is not appropriately clean.
<b>It was said</b> that the Sages disagreed over a similar issue: What is the legal status of <b>a foul odor that</b> emanates from a visible <b>source? Rav Huna said: He distances himself four cubits</b> from the source of the odor <b>and recites <i>Shema</i>. And Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The source is irrelevant; <b>he distances himself four cubits from the place that the odor ceased and recites <i>Shema</i>.</b>
The Gemara notes that <b>it was taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda: A person may not recite <i>Shema</i> opposite human excrement, dog excrement, pig excrement, chicken excrement, a foul-smelling dung-heap</b> or anything repulsive. <b>However, if</b> the filth <b>were in a place ten handbreadths above or ten handbreadths below</b> him, <b>he may sit alongside it and recite <i>Shema</i>,</b> as a height disparity of ten handbreadths renders it a separate domain. <b>And if</b> the filth were <b>not</b> ten handbreadths above or below him, <b>he must distance himself</b> until it remains beyond <b>his range of vision. And the same is true of prayer.</b> However, from <b>a foul odor with a</b> visible <b>source, he distances himself four cubits from the place</b> that <b>the odor</b> ceased <b>and recites <i>Shema</i>.</b>
<b>Rava said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with this <i>baraita</i> in all of these rulings,</b> but <b>rather in accordance with that which was taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may neither recite <i>Shema</i> opposite human excrement</b> under all circumstances, <b>nor opposite pig excrement, nor opposite dog excrement into which skins had been placed</b> for tanning, but other materials do not defile the venue of prayer.
<b>They raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: What is</b> the legal status of <b>a foul odor that has no</b> visible <b>source,</b> e.g., flatulence? <b>He said to them: Come and see these mats in the study hall, as these</b> students <b>are sleeping</b> on them <b>and these</b> other students <b>are studying,</b> and they are not concerned about foul odors. <b>However, this only applies to Torah study</b> because there is no alternative, <b>but not to the recitation of <i>Shema</i>. And with regard to Torah study we said</b> that it is permitted <b>only</b> when the odor originated <b>with another, but not</b> when it originated <b>with himself.</b>
<b>It was stated</b> that the Sages disagreed over a parallel issue: What is the law with regard to <b>feces passing</b> before him, being moved from place to place? <b>Abaye stated: One is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i></b> opposite it, <b>while Rava said: One is forbidden to recite <i>Shema</i></b> opposite it.
<b>Abaye said: From where do I say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? I say this on the basis of what <b>we learned</b> in a mishna: One who is afflicted with biblical leprosy renders the area beneath any covering under which he is located ritually impure. In a case where <b>the ritually impure</b> leper <b>is standing under</b> the branches of <b>a tree and a ritually pure</b> person <b>passes</b> under the branches of that same tree, the pure person <b>is</b> rendered <b>impure,</b> as the entire area under that covering is impure. However, if the <b>pure person is standing under the tree and the impure</b> leper <b>passes, he</b> remains <b>pure. And if</b> the leper <b>stopped</b> under the tree, the pure person is immediately rendered <b>impure. The same is true with regard to a stone afflicted</b> with biblical leprosy (see Leviticus 14), in that if it is merely being moved from place to place, it does not cause impurity. The upshot is that impurity is only disseminated in all directions when the source of the impurity is stationary.
<b>And Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: There,</b> in the case of leprosy, <b>it is contingent upon the permanence</b> of the place, <b>as</b> with regard to the leper <b>it is written: “He shall dwell alone; outside the camp shall his dwelling be”</b> (Leviticus 13:46). His impurity is in his permanent dwelling-place. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the obligation to distance oneself from something repulsive, <b>the Torah stated</b> the principle: <b>“And your camp shall be holy”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:15), <b>and there is no</b> holiness in those circumstances.
On this topic <b>Rav Pappa said: The mouth of a pig is like passing feces.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>That is obvious.</b> The Gemara replies: <b>No,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is only <b>necessary</b> to teach that <b>even though</b> the pig <b>emerged from the river</b> and one might assume that its mouth was thereby cleansed, it never becomes completely clean.
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> If there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to the presence of <b>feces,</b> e.g., whether something is or is not feces, and therefore whether or not one is permitted to utter sacred matters in its presence, <b>it is prohibited</b> to do so. However, if there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to the presence of <b>urine, it is permitted</b> to do so. <b>Some say</b> an alternative version of this. <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> If there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to the presence of <b>feces, in the home</b> one may assume that there is no feces present and <b>it is permitted</b> to speak sacred matters, but if there is doubt as to the presences of feces <b>in the dung-heap</b> it is <b>forbidden</b> to do so. If there is <b>uncertainty</b> as to the presence of <b>urine,</b> however, <b>even in the dung-heap it is permitted</b> to do so.
<b>He holds in accordance with that which Rav Hamnuna</b> said, <b>as Rav Hamnuna said: The Torah prohibited</b> the utterance of sacred matters <b>only opposite the stream</b> of urine.
<b>And in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan, as Rabbi Yonatan</b> raised a <b>contradiction</b> between two verses: On the one hand <b>it is written: “You shall also have a place outside the camp, to which you will go”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:13), meaning that one must exit the camp before attending to his bodily needs but there is no obligation to cover it; <b>and it is written</b> in another verse: <b>“And you shall have a spade</b> among your weapons; and when you ease yourself outside, you shall dig with it, and turn back <b>and cover your excrement”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:14), indicating a clear obligation to conceal one’s excrement.
He resolves this contradiction: <b>How is this</b> resolved? <b>Here,</b> where one is required to conceal his bodily needs, <b>it refers to feces; here,</b> where there is no requirement to conceal his bodily needs, <b>it refers to urine. Consequently,</b> with regard to <b>urine,</b> reciting <i>Shema</i> <b>was only prohibited by Torah law opposite the stream</b> of urine, <b>but once it has fallen to the ground, it is permitted. And the Sages are those who issued a decree with regard to</b> urine. <b>And when they issued a decree, it was only in</b> a case of <b>their certain</b> presence, <b>but in</b> a case of <b>their uncertain</b> presence, <b>they did not issue a decree.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In a case of the certain</b> presence of urine, <b>until when</b> and in what state does its presence preclude one from uttering sacred matters? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: As long as it</b> is wet enough to <b>moisten</b> the hands of one who touches it. <b>And so too Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: As long as it moistens. And so too Ulla said: As long as it moistens. Geniva in the name of Rav said:</b> It is forbidden <b>as long as its mark is apparent</b> on the ground.
<b>Rav Yosef said: May</b> God, <b>his Master, forgive Geniva,</b> as Rav could have said no such thing. <b>Now,</b> in the case of <b>feces, Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Once its surface has</b> dried sufficiently to form a <b>crust, one is permitted</b> to utter sacred matters opposite it; <b>is it necessary</b> to say that opposite <b>urine</b> it is permitted once it dries?
<b>Abaye said to him: What did you see that</b> led <b>you to rely on that</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rely on this</b> <i>halakha</i>; <b>as Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> Uttering sacred matters opposite <b>feces, even</b> if it is as dry <b>as earthenware, is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>feces like earthenware? Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: As long as one throws it and it does not crumble,</b> it is still considered moist. <b>And some say: As long as one</b> can <b>roll it</b> from place to place <b>and it does not crumble.</b>
<b>Ravina said: I was standing before Rav Yehuda of Difti</b> when <b>he saw feces. He said to me: Examine</b> it and see <b>whether or not its surface has</b> dried sufficiently to form a <b>crust. Some say</b> that <b>he said to him as follows: Examine</b> it and see <b>if it is cracked,</b> as only then is it considered dry.
Since several opinions were expressed on the subject, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion was reached <b>about this? It was stated</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is subject to dispute: Reciting sacred matters opposite <b>feces</b> as dry <b>as earthenware; Ameimar said: It is prohibited, and Mar Zutra said: It is permitted. Rava said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is: Opposite <b>feces</b> as dry <b>as earthenware it is prohibited, and</b> opposite <b>urine,</b> it is prohibited <b>as long as it moistens.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Urine, as long as it moistens it is prohibited. If it was absorbed</b> into the ground <b>or dried</b> in place, <b>it is permitted. What, is</b> urine that was <b>absorbed not similar</b> to urine that <b>dried? Just as when it dries its mark is no</b> longer <b>apparent, so too when it is absorbed, its mark is no</b> longer <b>apparent</b> and then it is permissible. <b>But</b> when <b>its mark is apparent, it is prohibited, even though it no longer moistens.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty to counter this: <b>And according to your reasoning, say the first clause: As long as it moistens it is prohibited,</b> from which one can infer: <b>But if</b> it does not moisten, but <b>its mark is apparent, it is permitted. Rather, no</b> inference beyond its basic meaning <b>can be deduced from this</b> <i>baraita</i>, as the inferences are contradictory.
The Gemara notes: <b>Let us say</b> that this is <b>parallel to a</b> dispute between <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It is forbidden to recite <i>Shema</i> opposite a vessel from which urine was poured. However, the urine itself that was poured,</b> if it <b>was absorbed it is permitted;</b> if it <b>was not absorbed, it is prohibited. Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> It is prohibited <b>as long as it moistens.</b>
The Gemara clarifies this dispute: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>absorbed and not absorbed in what the first <i>tanna</i> says? If you say</b> that <b>absorbed</b> means that it <b>does not moisten and not absorbed</b> means that it <b>moistens, and Rabbi Yosei came to say: As long as it moistens it is prohibited, but</b> if there is no moisture but its <b>mark is apparent, it is permitted.</b> If so, <b>that is</b> identical to the opinion of the <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> and there is no dispute at all. <b>Rather, absorbed</b> means that <b>its mark is not apparent</b> and <b>not absorbed</b> means that <b>its mark is apparent. And Rabbi Yosei came to say: As long as it moistens, it is prohibited, but</b> if there is no moisture but its <b>mark is apparent, it is permitted,</b> in which case the dispute in our Gemara is parallel to this tannaitic dispute.
The Gemara states that it is not necessarily parallel: <b>No, everyone,</b> both <i>tanna’im</i>, agrees that <b>as long as it moistens, it is prohibited,</b> and if there is no moisture but its <b>mark is apparent, it is permitted.</b>

Daf 25b

<b>And here, the difference between them is</b> in a case <b>where it is moist enough to moisten</b> other things. According to the first <i>tanna</i> the prohibition is only in effect when the urine is moist enough to moisten other objects, while according to Rabbi Yosei it applies as long as the urine itself is moist, even if it is not moist enough to moisten other objects.
We learned in a mishna that <b>one who descended to immerse himself</b> due to a seminal emission must calculate, <b>whether or not he is able to ascend,</b> cover himself with a garment and recite the morning <i>Shema</i> before sunrise. The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught</b> this in the <b>unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said:</b> One may recite <i>Shema</i> <b>until sunrise.</b>
The Gemara immediately rejects this assumption: <b>Even if you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who disagrees with Rabbi Eliezer and holds that one may recite the morning <i>Shema</i> until the third hour of the day, <b>and perhaps</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna was directed toward those whose practice was <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of the <b><i>vatikin</i>,</b> pious individuals who were scrupulous in their performance of mitzvot, with regard to whom <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>vatikin</i> would conclude</b> the recitation of <i>Shema</i> <b>with sunrise.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if</b> one calculates that he will <b>not</b> be able to ascend and cover himself with a garment in time to recite <i>Shema</i>, he should <b>cover himself in the water and recite</b> <i>Shema</i> there. The Gemara asks: How can one recite <i>Shema</i> with his head above water? <b>His heart sees</b> his <b>nakedness</b> as there is no barrier between them.
Regarding this <b>Rabbi Elazar said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Aḥa bar Abba bar Aḥa in the name of Rabbeinu,</b> Rav: <b>This was taught with regard to murky water, which is</b> considered to be <b>like solid earth.</b> Therefore, it constitutes a barrier so that <b>his heart does not see</b> his <b>nakedness.</b>
On this same topic, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one was in <b>clear water, he should sit in it up to his neck and recite <i>Shema</i>. And some say: He sullies</b> the water <b>with his foot.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the first <i>tanna</i> doesn’t his heart see</b> his <b>nakedness</b> through the clear water? The Gemara replies: <b>He holds</b> that even if <b>his heart sees</b> his <b>nakedness, it is permitted</b> to recite <i>Shema</i>. The Gemara continues and asks: <b>But</b> in the clear water, <b>doesn’t his heel see</b> his <b>nakedness?</b> The Gemara replies: Here too, the first <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that in a case where <b>his heel sees</b> his <b>nakedness</b> it is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara notes, <b>it was stated:</b> If <b>one’s heel sees</b> his <b>nakedness it is permitted.</b> However, what is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where his heel <b>touches</b> his nakedness? May one in that circumstance recite <i>Shema</i> or not? <b>Abaye said: It is prohibited, and Rava said: It is permitted.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Zevid taught this <i>halakha</i> in that manner. Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rav Ika, taught it as follows:</b> In a case where his heel <b>touches</b> his nakedness, <b>everyone agrees that it is prohibited.</b> Their dispute is with regard to a case where his heel <b>sees</b> his nakedness. <b>Abaye said: It is prohibited, and Rava said: It is permitted; the Torah was not given to the ministering angels,</b> and a person, who, as opposed to a ministering angel, has genitals, cannot avoid this. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that if his heel <b>touches</b> his nakedness <b>it is prohibited,</b> but if it merely <b>sees</b> his nakedness, <b>it is permitted.</b>
<b>Rava said: Opposite feces</b> covered only <b>by</b> a <b>lantern</b>-like covering, which is transparent, <b>it is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>.</b> But <b>opposite nakedness</b> covered only <b>by</b> a <b>lantern-</b>like covering, <b>it is prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i>. Opposite feces in a lantern, it is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i></b> because with regard to <b>feces,</b> the ability to recite <i>Shema</i> <b>is contingent upon covering,</b> as it is said: “And cover your excrement” (Deuteronomy 23:14), <b>and</b> although it is visible, <b>it is covered.</b> On the other hand, <b>opposite nakedness</b> covered only <b>by</b> a <b>lantern-</b>like covering, <b>it is prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i>; the Torah said: “And no indecent thing shall be seen in you”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:15), <b>and</b> here <b>it is seen.</b>
<b>Abaye said: A small amount of feces may be nullified with spittle,</b> and as long as it is covered, it is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>. <b>Rava said:</b> This applies specifically when it is <b>thick spittle. Rava said: Feces in a hole</b> in the ground, <b>he places his sandal over</b> the hole to cover <b>it and recites <i>Shema</i>. Mar, son of Ravina, raised a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>feces is stuck to his sandal?</b> Perhaps he would be considered filthy in that case? <b>Let</b> this dilemma <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: Opposite a naked gentile, it is forbidden to recite <i>Shema</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why did</b> Rav Yehuda discuss <b>particularly</b> the case of <b>a gentile? Even with regard to a Jew</b> it is <b>also</b> prohibited. The Gemara replies: Opposite the nakedness of <b>a Jew, it is obvious</b> that it is <b>prohibited; however,</b> opposite the nakedness of <b>a gentile, it was necessary for him</b> to say. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since it is written about</b> gentiles: <b>“Their flesh is the flesh of donkeys”</b> (Ezekiel 23:20), <b>say</b> that his nakedness <b>is like</b> that of <b>a mere donkey</b> and does not constitute nakedness. Rav Yehuda <b>taught us that their</b> nakedness <b>is also considered nakedness, as it is written</b> regarding the sons of Noah: <b>“And their father’s nakedness they did not see”</b> (Genesis 9:23). Although Noah predated Abraham and was consequently not Jewish, his nakedness is mentioned.
And we learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> one who needs to recite <i>Shema</i> <b>may not cover himself with either foul water or water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked until he pours</b> other <b>water into it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How much water does he continue to pour</b> in order to render them a permissible covering. If he is covering himself in water in which flax was soaked, it must be a considerable amount of water, requiring at least an equally considerable amount of water to neutralize it. <b>Rather, this is what it says: One may neither cover himself with foul water nor water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked at all; and urine,</b> which is considered repugnant, <b>until he adds</b> clean <b>water to it, and</b> only then <b>he may</b> recite <i>Shema</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> a related disagreement in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How much water must one add</b> in order <b>to</b> nullify urine? <b>Any quantity</b> is sufficient. <b>Rabbi Zakkai says:</b> One must add a <b>quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is with regard to a case where the urine is already in a vessel, and <b>afterward</b> one seeks to nullify it. <b>However,</b> if the clean water was in a vessel <b>at the beginning,</b> before the urine, each drop of urine is nullified as it enters the vessel and therefore <b>any amount</b> of clean water in the vessel is sufficient.
<b>And Rav Yosef said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is with regard to the amount of water necessary to have in the vessel <b>at the beginning,</b> before the urine. <b>However, afterward, everyone agrees</b> that <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> is required. The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yosef said to his servant</b> at the beginning: <b>Bring me a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of water, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Zakkai.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> an elaboration of this point in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Opposite a chamber pot</b> used for <b>excrement or urine, it is prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i>, even if there is nothing in it,</b> as it is always considered filthy. <b>Opposite urine itself,</b> one may not recite <i>Shema</i> <b>until he pours water into it. And how much water must he pour into it? Any quantity. Rabbi Zakkai says: A quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. That is the ruling <b>both</b> when it is <b>before the bed and</b> when it is <b>behind the bed. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> When it is <b>behind the bed, one may recite</b> <i>Shema</i>, but when it is <b>before the bed, one may not recite</b> <i>Shema</i>, <b>but he</b> must <b>distance himself four cubits and</b> only then <b>recite</b> <i>Shema</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> is even more strict, <b>saying: Even</b> in <b>a house one hundred cubits</b> in size, <b>one may not recite</b> <i>Shema</i> <b>until he removes it or places it beneath the bed.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised</b> before students at the yeshiva: <b>How does</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>state</b> this <i>halakha</i>? What did he mean? Did he mean that if the chamber pot is <b>behind the bed, he recites</b> <i>Shema</i> <b>immediately; before the bed, he distances himself four cubits and recites? Or perhaps he states the following:</b> If the chamber pot is <b>behind the bed, he distances himself four cubits and then recites</b> <i>Shema,</i> but if it is <b>before the bed he may not recite</b> <i>Shema</i> <b>at all?</b>
In order to resolve this dilemma, the Gemara cites proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> If it is <b>behind the bed he recites</b> <i>Shema</i> <b>immediately; before the bed, he distances himself four cubits. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even</b> in <b>a</b> large <b>house of one hundred cubits one may not recite</b> <i>Shema</i> <b>until he removes it or places it beneath the bed.</b> Thus we see from this <i>baraita</i> that if the vessel is obstructed by the bed he may recite <i>Shema</i> immediately.
The Gemara notes: <b>Our dilemma has been resolved,</b> but <b>the <i>baraitot</i> contradict each other.</b> The statements made in the name of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel in one <i>baraita</i> were made in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar in the other. The Gemara resolves the contradiction: <b>Reverse</b> the <b>latter</b> <i>baraita</i> and say that the names of the <i>tanna’im</i> were attached to the wrong opinions.
This solution is difficult: <b>What did you see</b> that led you to <b>reverse</b> the <b>latter</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>Reverse the first</b> one.
The Gemara proves that the latter <i>baraita</i> should be reversed in accordance with the opinions expressed by these Sages in general. <b>Who did you hear</b> that <b>said that an entire house is considered like four cubits? It is Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> who expressed that opinion in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>eiruv</i> (Rav Nissim). Consequently, it is reasonable to posit that this would also be his opinion with regard to these <i>halakhot</i>, and the <i>baraita</i> was reversed accordingly.
<b>Rav Yosef said: I raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: It is obvious to me that a bed</b> under which there is a space of <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>is considered connected [<i>lavud</i>]</b> to the ground as if the void beneath it does not exist, as <i>halakha</i> considers a void of less than three handbreadths as sealed. What, then, is the dilemma? <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if that space is <b>three, four, five, six, seven, eight</b> or <b>nine</b> handbreadths? <b>He said to him: I do not know.</b> However, with regard to a space greater than <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>I certainly have no dilemma,</b> as it is clear that this space is considered a separate domain. <b>Abaye said</b> to him: <b>You did well that you did not have a dilemma,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>any</b> space <b>ten</b> handbreadths high <b>is a separate domain.</b>
<b>Rava</b> summarized and <b>said: The <i>halakha</i> is that less than three</b> handbreadths <b>is considered connected</b> and it is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i>. <b>Ten</b> handbreadths <b>is a separate domain. Three to ten</b> handbreadths is the case with regard to which <b>Rav Yosef raised a dilemma before Rav Huna,</b> and Rav Huna <b>did not resolve it for him. Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. And, so too,</b> the Sage <b>Bali said</b> that <b>Rav Ya’akov, son of Shmuel’s daughter, said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. And Rava said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Aḥai arranged for his son</b> to marry into <b>the family</b> of <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta. He</b> led <b>him to enter the wedding canopy</b> for the wedding ceremony, <b>but he was unsuccessful</b> in his attempts to consummate the marriage. Rav Aḥai <b>followed him to examine</b> possible causes of the problem and <b>he saw a Torah scroll placed</b> there. <b>He said to them: Had I not come now, you would have endangered</b> the life of <b>my son. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In a room in which there is a Torah scroll or phylacteries, it is forbidden to engage in conjugal relations until he takes them out</b> of the room <b>or places them in a vessel inside a</b> second <b>vessel.</b>
<b>Abaye said: They only taught</b> that a vessel inside a second vessel is sufficient <b>when the vessel is not their,</b> the Torah scroll’s or the phylacteries’, regular <b>vessel. But a vessel that is their</b> regular <b>vessel, even ten vessels are considered as one vessel,</b> and the Torah or phylacteries must be covered in another vessel not typically used for that purpose. <b>Rava said: A cloak</b>

Daf 26a

<b>atop a chest is like a vessel within a vessel.</b> On a similar note, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> One who wishes to engage in marital relations in a room in which there is <b>a Torah scroll, must erect a partition ten</b> handbreadths high. The Gemara relates: <b>Mar Zutra happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Ashi</b> and <b>he saw</b> that <b>in the</b> bed <b>chamber of</b> his son <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi, there was a Torah scroll, and a partition of ten</b> handbreadths <b>had been erected for it. He said to him: In accordance with whose</b> opinion did you do this? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi? Say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said</b> this only as a makeshift solution in exigent situations, when <b>he has no other room</b> in which to place it, but <b>don’t</b> you, <b>Master, have another room</b> where you could place the Torah scroll? <b>He said to him:</b> Indeed, <b>that</b> did <b>not</b> enter <b>my mind.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And, how far must one distance himself from urine and from feces</b> in order to recite <i>Shema</i>? <b>Four cubits. Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Seḥora said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said: They only taught</b> that it is sufficient to distance oneself four cubits when the feces are <b>behind him, but</b> if they are <b>before him he must distance himself</b> to the point that it is <b>no longer within his range of vision;</b> and the <i>halakha</i> <b>is the same</b> for <b>prayer.</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rafram bar Pappa say</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: One may stand opposite a bathroom and pray.</b> The Gemara resolves this contradiction: <b>With what are we dealing here? With a bathroom that has no feces,</b> and therefore there is no need to distance himself to that extent.
The Gemara asks again: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Yosef bar Ḥanina say: The bathroom to which</b> the Sages <b>referred</b> in all of the <i>halakhot</i> of distancing oneself was <b>even</b> one <b>in which there were no feces, and the bathhouse to which</b> the Sages <b>referred</b> in all of the <i>halakhot</i> of uttering sacred matters, was <b>even</b> one <b>in which there was no</b> naked <b>person. Rather, with what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with a new</b> structure, built as a bathroom but not yet used for that purpose.
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t this</b> already <b>raised as a dilemma</b> by <b>Ravina: One who designated</b> the structure for use <b>as a bathroom, what is its</b> legal status? Is <b>designation</b> effective <b>or is designation not</b> effective? The Gemara replies: <b>When Ravina raised the dilemma,</b> it was whether or not one may <b>stand and pray inside it, but</b> he had <b>no</b> dilemma whether or <b>not one may pray opposite it.</b>
<b>Rava said: These Persian bathrooms, even though they contain feces, they are considered as sealed,</b> as they are constructed on an incline so the feces will roll out of the bathroom underground.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Continuing the earlier discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> of immersion for Torah study and prayer for one who experienced a seminal emission, the mishna discusses a case where individuals who were already impure with a severe form of ritual impurity are exposed to the impurity of a seminal emission as well. They are required to immerse themselves and purify themselves of the impurity of the seminal emission even though they remain impure due to the more severe impurity. Consequently, even a <b><i>zav</i>,</b> whose impurity lasts at least seven days, <b>who experienced a seminal emission,</b> for which, were he not a <i>zav</i>, he would be impure for only one day; <b>a menstruating woman who discharged semen,</b> despite the fact that she is already impure with a severe impurity unaffected by her immersion; <b>and</b> a woman <b>who engaged in conjugal relations</b> with her husband <b>and</b> later <b>saw menstrual blood,</b> all <b>require immersion. And Rabbi Yehuda exempts</b> them from immersion.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the students of the yeshiva: <b>One who experienced a seminal emission</b> and was therefore required to immerse himself, who later <b>saw a discharge</b> that rendered him a <b><i>zav</i>; according to Rabbi Yehuda, what is his legal status?</b> The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>When,</b> in our mishna, <b>Rabbi Yehuda exempted a <i>zav</i> who saw a seminal emission</b> from immersion, that <b>was because from the outset he was not fit for immersion,</b> as the immersion would not be effective in purifying him from the impurity of a <i>zav</i>; <b>however, one who experienced a seminal emission,</b> who later <b>saw a discharge</b> that rendered him a <b><i>zav</i>,</b> who <b>was fit for immersion</b> and only later became impure with the severe impurity of a <i>zav</i>, would Rabbi Yehuda <b>require</b> immersion? <b>Or perhaps there is no difference</b> and he is exempt from immersion in both cases?
In order to resolve this dilemma, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> the last case of the mishna: A woman <b>who engaged in conjugal relations</b> with her husband <b>and</b> later <b>saw menstrual blood requires immersion. And Rabbi Yehuda exempts</b> them from immersion. <b>Isn’t the</b> woman <b>who engaged in conjugal relations</b> with her husband <b>and</b> later <b>saw menstrual blood like one who experienced a seminal emission,</b> who later <b>saw a discharge</b> that rendered him a <b><i>zav</i>,</b> as in both cases there is a less severe ritual impurity followed by a more severe impurity; <b>and</b> nevertheless, <b>Rabbi Yehuda exempts. Conclude from this</b> that Rabbi Yehuda does not distinguish between the cases. And indeed, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya explicitly taught: One who experienced a seminal emission</b> who later <b>saw a discharge</b> that rendered him a <b><i>zav</i> requires immersion, and Rabbi Yehuda exempts.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This mishna determines the times beyond which the different prayers may not be recited. According to the Rabbis, <b>the morning prayer</b> may be recited <b>until noon. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It may be recited only <b>until four hours</b> after sunrise. According to the Rabbis, <b>the afternoon prayer</b> may be recited <b>until the evening. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It may be recited only <b>until the midpoint of the afternoon [<i>pelag haminḥa</i>],</b> i.e., the midpoint of the period that begins with the sacrifice of the daily afternoon offering and ends at nightfall, which is the end of the afternoon.
<b>The evening prayer</b> may be recited throughout the night and <b>is not fixed</b> to a specific hour. According to the Rabbis, <b>the additional prayer</b> may be recited <b>all day. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It may be recited only <b>until seven hours</b> after sunrise.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that the morning prayer may be recited only until a few hours into the day. The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The mitzva</b> is to recite the morning <i>Shema</i> <b>with sunrise</b> so that <b>he will juxtapose redemption,</b> which is mentioned in the blessings following <i>Shema</i>, <b>to</b> the <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer,</b> which is recited immediately after sunrise, and <b>find</b> himself <b>praying in the daytime.</b> Clearly, the time to recite the morning prayer is immediately after sunrise.
The Gemara responds: This <i>baraita</i> does not establish a binding <i>halakha</i>. Rather, it <b>taught that</b> rule specifically <b>with regard to those who are scrupulous in fulfillment of mitzvot [<i>vatikin</i>]. As Rabbi Yoḥanan said: <i>Vatikin</i> would finish</b> reciting the morning <i>Shema</i> <b>with sunrise,</b> but those who are not <i>vatikin</i> may recite their prayers later.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does everyone</b> hold that one may recite the morning prayer only <b>until noon and no later? Didn’t Rav Mari, son of Rav Huna, son of Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba, say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who erred and did not recite the evening prayer, prays in the morning prayer two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers; one who erred and did not recite <b>the morning prayer, prays in the afternoon prayer two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers? Apparently, the morning prayer may be recited until the evening, at least in the event that he forgot to recite it in the morning.
The Gemara answers: Indeed, <b>one may continue praying for the entire day.</b> However, if he prayed <b>until noon, they give him a reward for</b> reciting the <b>prayer at its</b> appointed <b>time.</b> If he prayed <b>from there on, they give him a reward for</b> reciting the <b>prayer. They do not give him a reward for</b> reciting the <b>prayer at its</b> appointed <b>time.</b>
On the topic of one who forgot to pray and seeks to compensate for the prayer that he missed, <b>a dilemma was raised before them</b> in the study hall: <b>One who erred and did not recite the afternoon prayer, what is</b> the ruling? May he <b>recite</b> in <b>the evening prayer two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers? The Gemara articulates the sides of the dilemma: <b>If you say</b> that <b>one who erred and did not pray the evening prayer prays in the morning prayer two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers, perhaps that is <b>because</b> the evening and the morning are both part of <b>one day, as it is written: “And there was evening and there was morning, one day”</b> (Genesis 1:5); the evening and the following morning constitute a single unit. <b>But here,</b> in the case under discussion, perhaps <b>prayer is in place of sacrifice.</b> Since in the case of sacrifice we say, <b>since its day passed, its sacrifice is invalid</b> and there is no way to compensate for the missed opportunity, the same should be true for prayer. <b>Or, perhaps, since prayer is supplication, any time that one wishes, he may continue to pray?</b>
<b>Come and hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that <b>which Rav Huna bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who erred and did not recite the afternoon prayer, prays in the evening prayer two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers <b>and there is no element of: Its day passed, its sacrifice is invalid.</b>
With regard to the possibility to compensate for a prayer that he failed to recite at its appointed time, the Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>. The meaning of the verse: <b>“That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered”</b> (Ecclesiastes 1:15), is as follows: <b>That which is crooked cannot be made straight</b> refers to <b>one who omitted the evening <i>Shema</i> and the morning <i>Shema,</i> or the evening prayer, or the morning prayer. And that which is wanting cannot be numbered [<i>lehimanot</i>]</b> refers to <b>one whose friends reached a consensus [<i>nimnu</i>]</b> to perform <b>a mitzva and he was not part of their consensus [<i>nimnu</i>]</b> and, consequently, he missed his opportunity to join them in performance of the mitzva. This <i>baraita</i> clearly states that there is no way to compensate for a missed prayer.
To resolve this difficulty, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: With what are we dealing here</b> in this <i>baraita</i>? We are dealing with a case where one <b>intentionally failed</b> to recite the prayer. Only then he has no remedy. However, one who failed to pray due to error can compensate for the missed prayer by reciting the next prayer twice.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise as it teaches omitted and did not teach erred.</b> This indicates that the <i>halakha</i> is different in the case of error. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this.</b>

Daf 26b

On a similar note, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who erred and did not recite the afternoon prayer on the eve of Shabbat, prays in</b> the evening prayer <b>two</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers <b>on Shabbat evening. One who erred and did not recite the afternoon prayer on Shabbat, recites two weekday</b> <i>Amida</i> prayers in the evening prayer <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat. He recites <i>havdala</i> [</b>the prayer of <b>distinction]</b> between the sanctity of Shabbat and the profanity of the week by reciting: You have graced us, etc., in the fourth blessing of the <i>Amida,</i> which is: Who graciously grants knowledge, <b>in the first</b> prayer, as it is the actual evening prayer, <b>but he does not recite <i>havdala</i> in the second</b> prayer, which is in place of the afternoon prayer. Moreover, <b>if he recited <i>havdala</i> in the second</b> prayer <b>and did not recite <i>havdala</i> in the first, the second prayer fulfilled his</b> obligation, the <b>first one did not fulfill his</b> obligation.
The Gemara comments: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>since he did not recite <i>havdala</i> in the first</b> prayer, he is <b>as one who did not pray and we require him to return</b> to the beginning of the prayer and repeat it? If so, the conclusion is that one who fails to recite <i>havdala</i> in the prayer must repeat that prayer.
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to the above conclusion from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who erred and did not mention the might of the rains:</b> He makes the wind blow and rain fall <b>in</b> the second blessing of the <i>Amida</i>, the blessing on <b>the revival of the dead, and</b> one who erred and failed to recite <b>the request</b> for rain <b>in</b> the ninth blessing of the <i>Amida</i>, <b>the blessing of the years, we require him to return</b> to the beginning of the prayer and repeat it. However, one who erred and failed to recite <b><i>havdala</i> in</b> the blessing: <b>Who graciously grants knowledge, we do not require him to return</b> to the beginning of the prayer and repeat it, <b>as he can recite</b> <i>havdala</i> <b>over the cup</b> of wine, independent of his prayer. This contradiction was not resolved and remains <b>difficult.</b>
The dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda with regard to the times beyond which the different prayers may not be recited is rooted in a profound disagreement, also manifest in a later amoraic dispute. <b>It was stated: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> The practice of praying three times daily is ancient, albeit not in its present form; <b>prayers were instituted by the Patriarchs.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said</b> that the <b>prayers were instituted based on the daily offerings</b> sacrificed in the Holy Temple, and the prayers parallel the offerings, in terms of both time and characteristics.
The Gemara comments: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, and it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: Abraham instituted the morning prayer, as it is stated</b> when Abraham came to look out over Sodom the day after he had prayed on its behalf: <b>“And Abraham rose early in the morning to the place where he had stood</b> before the Lord” (Genesis 19:27), <b>and</b> from the context as well as the language utilized in the verse, the verb <b>standing</b> means <b>nothing other than prayer,</b> as this language is used to describe Pinehas’ prayer after the plague, <b>as it is stated: “And Pinehas stood up and prayed</b> and the plague ended” (Psalms 106:30). Clearly, Abraham was accustomed to stand in prayer in the morning.
<b>Isaac instituted the afternoon prayer, as it is stated: “And Isaac went out to converse [<i>lasuaḥ</i>] in the field toward evening”</b> (Genesis 24:63), <b>and conversation</b> means <b>nothing other than prayer, as it is stated: “A prayer of the afflicted when he is faint and pours out his complaint [<i>siḥo</i>] before the Lord”</b> (Psalms 102:1). Obviously, Isaac was the first to pray as evening approached, at the time of the afternoon prayer.
<b>Jacob instituted the evening prayer, as it is stated: “And he encountered [<i>vayifga</i>] the place and he slept there</b> for the sun had set” (Genesis 28:11). The word <b>encounter</b> means <b>nothing other than prayer, as it is stated</b> when God spoke to Jeremiah: <b>“And you, do not pray on behalf of this nation and do not raise on their behalf song and prayer, and do not encounter [<i>tifga</i>] Me</b> for I do not hear you” (Jeremiah 7:16). Jacob prayed during the evening, after the sun had set.
<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> that the laws of prayer are based on the laws of the daily offerings: <b>Why did</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>the morning prayer</b> may be recited <b>until noon? Because,</b> although the <b>daily morning offering</b> is typically brought early in the morning, it may be <b>sacrificed until noon. And Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> My opinion, that the morning prayer may be recited <b>until four hours</b> into the day, is <b>because the daily morning offering is sacrificed until four hours.</b>
<b>And why did</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>the afternoon prayer</b> may be recited <b>until the evening? Because the daily afternoon offering is sacrificed until the evening. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>the afternoon prayer</b> may be recited only <b>until the midpoint of the afternoon because,</b> according to his opinion, <b>the daily afternoon offering is sacrificed until the midpoint of the afternoon.</b>
<b>And why did they say</b> that <b>the evening prayer is not fixed? Because</b> the burning of the <b>limbs and fats</b> of the offerings that were <b>not consumed</b> by the fire on the altar <b>until the evening.</b> They remained on the altar and were <b>offered continuously</b> throughout <b>the entire night.</b>
<b>And why did</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>the additional prayer</b> may be recited <b>all day? Because the additional offering is brought</b> throughout <b>the entire day.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>the additional prayer</b> may be recited <b>until the seventh hour</b> of the day, <b>because the additional offering is sacrificed until the seventh hour.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues and states that there are two times for the afternoon prayer. Greater, earlier <i>minḥa</i> [<i>minḥa gedola</i>] and lesser, later <i>minḥa</i> [<i>minḥa ketana</i>]. The Gemara clarifies the difference between them: <b>Which is <i>minḥa gedola</i>? From six-and-a-half hours</b> after sunrise <b>and on,</b> which is a half an hour after noon and on. It is the earliest time that the daily afternoon offering may be sacrificed, as in the case on the eve of Passover that occurs on Shabbat. <b>Which is <i>minḥa ketana</i>? From nine-and-a-half hours and on,</b> which is the standard time that the daily afternoon offering is sacrificed.
On that note, <b>a dilemma was raised before them: Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the afternoon prayer may be recited only until the midpoint of the afternoon, does <b>he say the midpoint of the first <i>minḥa</i>,</b> <i>minḥa gedola</i>? <b>Or,</b> does <b>he say the midpoint of the last <i>minḥa</i>? Come and hear</b> an explicit resolution to this dilemma: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They said the midpoint of the last <i>minḥa</i>, and that is eleven hours minus a quarter</b> of an hour after sunrise, i.e., an hour-and-a-quarter hours before sunset.
In any case, it is clear that according to this <i>baraita</i> the <i>halakhot</i> of prayer are based on the Temple offerings. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that this is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> who held that the forefathers instituted the prayers. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> could have <b>said to you: Actually, I will say to you</b> that <b>the Patriarchs instituted the prayers and the Sages based</b> the times and characteristics of prayer <b>on the Temple offerings,</b> even though they do not stem from the same source. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that even Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, would agree that the laws of offerings and those of prayers are related, <b>then, according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, who instituted the additional prayer?</b> It is not one of the prayers instituted by the forefathers. <b>Rather,</b> even according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>the prayers were instituted by the Patriarchs and the Sages based them</b> on the laws of the <b>offerings.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The morning prayer may be recited <b>until four hours</b> of the day. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the yeshiva students: When Rabbi Yehuda says <b>until,</b> does he mean <b>until and including</b> the fourth hour, <b>or, perhaps</b> when he says <b>“until”</b> he means <b>until and not including,</b> in which case one may not pray during the fourth hour? <b>Come and hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma based on the mishna. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The afternoon prayer may be recited only <b>until the midpoint of the afternoon.</b> Now, <b>granted, if you say</b> that <b>until</b> means <b>until and not including, then there is</b> a difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. However, if you say</b> that <b>until</b> means <b>until and including,</b> then the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b>

Daf 27a

<b>is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> as the end of the period that begins with the midpoint of the afternoon is sunset.
The Gemara immediately rejects this proof: <b>Rather, what</b> is the alternative? That <b>until</b> means <b>until and not including?</b> It remains problematic. <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>The additional prayer</b> may be recited <b>all day. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It may be recited <b>until the seven hours. And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> the obligation to recite <b>two prayers was before him, one the additional prayer and one the afternoon prayer, he prays the afternoon prayer</b> first <b>and the additional prayer thereafter,</b> because <b>this,</b> the afternoon prayer, <b>is</b> recited on a <b>frequent</b> basis, <b>and that,</b> the additional prayer, <b>is</b> recited on a relatively <b>infrequent</b> basis as it is only recited on Shabbat, the New Moon, and Festivals. The principle states: When a frequent practice and an infrequent practice clash, the frequent practice takes precedence over the infrequent practice. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He recites the additional prayer</b> first <b>and the afternoon prayer thereafter,</b> because the time to recite <b>this, the additional prayer,</b> will soon <b>elapse, and this,</b> the time to recite <b>the afternoon prayer,</b> will <b>not</b> soon <b>elapse,</b> as one may recite it until the midpoint of the afternoon.
The relevant point is: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>until</b> means <b>until and including, that is how you can find</b> a situation where the times to recite <b>two prayers,</b> the afternoon prayer and the additional prayer, <b>overlap. But if you say</b> that <b>until</b> means <b>until and not including,</b> and that until seven hours means until the beginning of the seventh hour, noon, then <b>how can you find</b> a situation where the times to recite <b>two prayers overlap? Once</b> the time to recite <b>the afternoon prayer,</b> a half hour past noon, <b>has arrived,</b> the time to recite <b>the additional prayer</b> is already <b>gone?</b>
<b>Rather, what</b> is the alternative? That <b>until</b> means <b>until and including?</b> Then <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>is difficult,</b> as explained above with regard to the midpoint of the afternoon: <b>What is</b> the halakhic difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Do you think that</b> when <b>this midpoint of the afternoon</b> was mentioned it was <b>speaking of</b> the period following <b>the midpoint, the last</b> part of the afternoon, from an hour-and-a-quarter before sunset until sunset? This was not the intention. Rather, it was <b>speaking of</b> the period prior to <b>the midpoint, the first</b> part of the afternoon, which, as explained above, is from nine-and-a-half hours after sunrise until an hour-and-a-quarter before sunset. Consequently, until the midpoint of the afternoon means until the end of the first half of that afternoon period. <b>And this is what he is saying: When does the first half leave and the second half enter? From when eleven hours minus a quarter have passed</b> since sunrise. Rabbi Yehuda’s use of the term until always means until and including.
Practically speaking, this means that, according to Rabbi Yehuda, it is permissible to recite the morning prayer until the end of the fourth hour. In support of this <b>Rav Naḥman said: We, too, learned</b> this in a mishna:
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava testified</b> about <b>five matters of</b> <i>halakha</i>: <br>When an orphan girl, who was married off by her mother or brother before reaching the age of majority, reaches the age of majority, she may refuse to continue living with her husband and thereby retroactively annul their marriage. Normally, marriage refusals are discouraged. However, in specific instances where it is clear that if the marriage were to remain in effect it would engender problems related to levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i>, Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava testified that <b>one may persuade the minor girl to refuse</b> to continue living with her husband, thereby resolving the complications involved in this case.<br><b>And</b> he testified <b>that one may</b> allow <b>a woman</b> who, after hearing of her husband’s death, seeks to remarry, <b>to marry based on</b> the testimony of <b>one witness,</b> as opposed to the two witnesses required for other testimonies of the Torah. <br><b>And</b> he testified <b>about a rooster that was stoned</b> to death <b>in Jerusalem for killing a person,</b> in order to teach that the Torah law (Exodus 21:28) which requires the stoning of an ox that killed a person, applies to other animals as well. <br><b>And</b> he testified <b>about forty-day-old wine that was</b> used for <b>libation on the altar.</b> <br><b>And</b> he testified <b>about</b> the <b>daily morning offering that was sacrificed at four hours</b> of the day.
<b>Learn from this</b> final testimony, which is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, that <b>until</b> means <b>until and including.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this.</b>
Based on this mishna, <b>Rav Kahana said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda since we learned</b> in a mishna in the <b>preferred</b> tractate, <i>Eduyyot</i>, <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion. Since the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with all of the <i>mishnayot</i> in <i>Eduyyot</i>, the opinion of a <i>tanna</i> who rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in that mishna means that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with that opinion.
<b>And about</b> the <b>daily morning offering that was sacrificed at four hours.</b> Based on this, the Gemara attempts to identify <b>the <i>tanna</i> who taught that which we learned</b> in the mishna about the manna that fell for the children of Israel in the desert: “And they gathered it morning by morning, each according to what he eats, <b>and when the sun grew hot it melted”</b> (Exodus 16:21); that took place <b>four hours</b> into the day.
The <i>baraita </i>continues: Do <b>you say</b> that the time when the sun grew hot was <b>at four hours, or</b> perhaps <b>it was only at six hours</b> of the day? <b>When</b> the verse <b>says: “In the heat of the day”</b> (Genesis 18:1), <b>six hours is</b> already <b>mentioned</b> in the Torah as the heat of the day. <b>How, then, do I establish</b> the verse: <b>“And when the sun grew hot it melted”?</b> This must refer to an earlier time, <b>at four hours.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> of this mishna? It is <b>neither Rabbi Yehuda nor the Sages. If</b> it was in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, until four hours is also</b> considered <b>morning,</b> as he holds that the daily morning offering may still be sacrificed then, while here it says that in the morning the manna was gathered and it melted after the morning. <b>If</b> it was in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, until noon is also</b> considered <b>morning,</b> since, according to the Sages, the daily morning offering could be sacrificed until noon. Apparently, this is an entirely new position.
The Gemara responds: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and <b>if you wish, say</b> instead that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>If you wish, say</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. The verse states: Morning by morning, divide it into two mornings.</b> Morning, according to the Rabbis, lasts until noon. The repetition of the term morning in the Torah indicates that the period when the manna was gathered ended at the conclusion of the first half of the morning, i.e., the end of the third hour. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who would say that: <b>This extra morning</b> in the phrase morning by morning comes to <b>make</b> the end of the period when the manna was gathered <b>an hour earlier.</b> In any event, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the verse, <b>And when the sun grew hot it melted,</b> refers to <b>four hours</b> of the day.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where is the inference</b> drawn that this is the meaning of the verse? <b>Rabbi Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: The verse states: “When the sun grew hot it melted.” Which is the hour that the sun is hot but the shade</b> remains <b>cool,</b> before the heat of the day, when even the shade is hot? <b>You must say at four hours.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The Rabbis hold that <b>the afternoon prayer</b> may be recited <b>until the evening.</b> Rabbi Yehuda says: It may be recited only until the midpoint of the afternoon. <b>Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Yitzḥak: There,</b> with regard to the morning prayer, <b>Rav Kahana said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, since we learned</b> in a mishna in the <b>preferred</b> tractate, <i>Eduyyot</i>, <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion. <b>Here, what</b> is the ruling? <b>He was silent and said nothing to him,</b> as he was familiar with no established ruling in this matter. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Let us see</b> and try to resolve this ourselves <b>from</b> the fact <b>that Rav prayed</b> the <b>Shabbat</b> prayers on the eve of Shabbat <b>while it was still day. Learn from this</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and the time for the afternoon prayer ends at the midpoint of the afternoon, after which time one may recite the evening prayer.
The Gemara immediately rejects the proof based on Rav’s practice: <b>On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that Rav Huna and the Sages,</b> students of Rav, <b>would not pray until evening, learn from that</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Now that the <i>halakha</i> was stated neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage nor in accordance with</b> the opinion of that <b>Sage, one who acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage has acted</b> legitimately, <b>and one who acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of that <b>Sage has acted</b> legitimately, as this <i>halakha</i> is left to the decision of each individual.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav happened by the house of</b> the Sage, <b>Geniva, and he prayed</b> the <b>Shabbat</b> prayer <b>on the eve of Shabbat</b> before nightfall. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba was praying behind Rav, and Rav finished</b> his prayer <b>but did not</b> take three steps back and <b>interrupt the prayer</b> of <b>Rabbi Yirmeya. Derive from this</b> incident <b>three</b> <i>halakhot</i>: <b>Derive from this</b> that <b>one may pray the Shabbat</b> prayer <b>on the eve of Shabbat</b> before nightfall. <b>And derive from this that a student</b> may <b>pray behind his rabbi. And derive from this</b> that it is <b>prohibited to pass before those who are praying.</b>
The Gemara responds: This <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: It is prohibited to pass before those who are praying.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi pass</b> before those who were praying? The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi</b> were <b>beyond four cubits</b> from those who were praying <b>when they passed.</b>
One particular detail was surprising: <b>How did Rabbi Yirmeya act that way</b> and pray behind Rav? <b>Didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav said: A person should never pray</b>

Daf 27b

directly <b>next to his rabbi,</b> presumptuously indicating that he is his rabbi’s equal, <b>and behind his rabbi</b> as it creates the impression that he is bowing to him (<i>Tosafot</i>)?
<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, in a more extreme manner, as <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One who prays behind his rabbi and one who greets his rabbi</b> without waiting for his rabbi to greet him first, <b>one who returns his rabbi’s greeting</b> without saying: Greetings to you, rabbi, <b>one who rivals his rabbi’s yeshiva,</b> i.e., establishes a yeshiva of his own and teaches during his rabbi’s lifetime without his consent (Rambam), <b>and one who says something</b> in the name of his rabbi <b>which he did not hear directly from his rabbi, causes the Divine Presence to withdraw from Israel.</b>
With regard to Rabbi Yirmeya’s conduct, the Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba is different,</b> as he was not a mere student of Rav. Rather, he <b>was a disciple-colleague</b> and was, therefore, permitted to act that way. <b>And that is why</b> on one occasion, when Rav prayed the Shabbat prayer early, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba asked him: Did you distance yourself</b> from labor and accept the sanctity of Shabbat? <b>Rav said to him: Yes, I distanced myself. And</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>did not say to him: Did the Master distance himself,</b> as would have been appropriate had he merely been Rav’s student.
