And when do</b> these coverings serve as <b>protection for the fruit? When the fruit is still young; and he,</b> nevertheless, <b>calls them protection for the fruit.</b> This indicates that in order to be considered protection for the fruit it need not remain until the fruit is fully ripened. The question remains: Why are the buds not accorded the same status as the berries of the caper-bush?
The Gemara explains that <b>Rav Naḥman held</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: The grape-bud,</b> i.e., a cluster of grapes in its earliest stage, immediately after the flowers dropped from the vine, <b>is prohibited</b> due to <i>orla</i>, <b>because it is</b> already considered <b>a fruit.</b> According to this opinion, even the date coverings that exist in the earliest stage of the ripening process are nevertheless considered protection for the fruit and prohibited due to <i>orla</i>. <b>The Rabbis disagree with him,</b> explaining that fruit at that stage is not considered fruit; and, therefore, the date coverings and caper-bush buds are not considered protection for the fruit and are not prohibited due to <i>orla</i>.
<b>Rav Shimi of Neharde’a strongly objects to this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>Do the Rabbis disagree with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yosei <b>with regard to</b> the fruits <b>of all other trees</b> besides grapes, that even in the very first stage of ripening, they are considered fruit? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to fruit, which grows during the Sabbatical year, the Torah says: “And the Shabbat of the land shall be to you for eating” (Leviticus 25:6). The Sages inferred, for eating, and not for loss. Because one is prohibited from discarding fruit grown during the Sabbatical year, the question is raised: <b>From when may one no</b> longer <b>cut trees during the Sabbatical year</b> as he thereby damages the fruit? <b>Beit Shammai say: All trees, from when</b> the blossoms fall off and <b>fruit</b> begins to <b>emerge</b> in its earliest stage. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> There is a distinction between different types of trees. <b>Carob trees</b> may not be cut <b>from when they</b> form <b>chains</b> of carobs, <b>vines</b> may not be cut <b><i>misheyegaru</i>,</b> explained below, <b>olives from when they blossom, and all other trees from when</b> fruit <b>emerges.</b>
<b>And Rav Asi said:</b> <i>Sheyegaru</i> in our mishna is to be understood: <b>It is an unripe grape, it is a grape kernel, it is a white bean.</b> Before this is even explained, the Gemara expresses its astonishment: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that the grape is, at any stage, <b>a white bean? Rather, say: Its size,</b> that of an unripe grape, is equivalent to the size <b>of a white bean.</b> In any case, <b>whom did you hear that said: An unripe grape, yes,</b> is considered fruit, while <b>a grape-bud, no,</b> is not considered fruit? Wasn’t it <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yosei, <b>and it is taught</b> that, according to these Sages, one is forbidden to cut <b>all other trees from when</b> fruit <b>emerges.</b> This indicates that even they agree that from the very beginning of the ripening process, the fruit is forbidden due to <i>orla</i>. The question remains: Why are the buds permitted?
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> a different explanation: <b>Where do we say</b> that a section of the plant <b>becomes protection for the fruit? Where if you remove the protection, the fruit dies. Here,</b> in the case of the caper-bush, <b>when you remove</b> the bud, <b>the fruit does not die.</b>
In fact, <b>there was an incident and they removed the flower of a pomegranate, and the pomegranate withered. And they removed the flower of the fruit of a caper-bush and the fruit of the caper-bush survived.</b> Therefore, buds are not considered protection for the fruit.
The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi, who discarded the berries and ate the buds. And since they are not</b> considered <b>fruit with regard to <i>orla</i>, they are also not</b> considered <b>fruit with regard to blessings, and one does not recite over them: Who creates fruit of the tree, but rather: Who creates fruit of the ground.</b>
The question arose with regard to the blessing over <b>peppers. Rav Sheshet said:</b> One who eats peppers must recite: <b>By Whose word all things came to be. Rava said: One</b> need <b>not recite</b> a blessing <b>at all.</b> <b>This is consistent with Rava’s opinion</b> that eating peppers is not considered eating, <b>as Rava said: One who chews on peppers on Yom Kippur is exempt, one who chews on ginger on Yom Kippur is exempt.</b> Eating sharp spices is an uncommon practice, and is therefore not considered to be eating, which is prohibited by Torah law on Yom Kippur.
<b>The Gemara raised an objection</b> to this based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>, that regarding the verse: “When you enter the land and plant any tree for food you shall regard its fruit as <i>orla</i>” (Leviticus 19:23), <b>Rabbi Meir would say: By inference from that which is stated: “You shall regard its fruit as <i>orla</i>,” don’t I know that it is</b> referring to <b>a tree</b> that produces <b>food? Rather,</b> for <b>what</b> purpose <b>does the verse state: “Any tree for food”? To include a tree whose wood and fruit have the same taste. And which</b> tree <b>is this? This is the pepper</b> tree. <b>And</b> this comes <b>to teach you that the peppers,</b> and even the wood portions, are edible and are therefore <b>obligated in</b> the prohibition of <b><i>orla</i>, and to teach that Eretz Yisrael lacks nothing, as it is stated: “A land where you shall eat bread without scarceness, you shall lack nothing”</b> (Deuteronomy 8:9). <b>Obviously,</b> peppers are fit for consumption.
The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is a distinction between two different cases. <b>This,</b> where Rabbi Meir spoke of peppers fit for consumption, <b>is</b> referring to a case <b>when it is damp</b> and fresh; <b>and this,</b> where chewing on pepper is not considered eating on Yom Kippur and does not require a blessing, <b>is</b> referring to a case <b>when it is dry.</b>
With regard to this discussion of chewing pepper on Yom Kippur, the Gemara cites what <b>the Sages said to Mareimar:</b> Why <b>is one who chews ginger on Yom Kippur exempt? Didn’t Rava say: One is permitted</b> to eat <b>the ginger that comes from India, and over it, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground.</b> With regard to blessing, it is considered edible; therefore, with regard to chewing on Yom Kippur, it should be considered edible as well. The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult. This,</b> where a blessing is recited, <b>is</b> referring to a case <b>when it is damp</b> and fresh; <b>this,</b> where no blessing is recited, <b>is</b> referring to a case <b>when it is dry.</b>
The Gemara cites a similar dispute with regard to the blessing be recited over <b><i>ḥavitz</i>,</b> a dish consisting of flour, oil, and honey cooked in a <b>pot as well as pounded grain. Rav Yehuda said</b> that one recites: <b>By Whose word all things came to be. Rav Kahana said</b> that one recites: <b>Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to pounded grain alone, everyone agrees that one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. When they argue, it is with regard to pounded grain</b> mixed with honey, <b>in the manner of a <i>ḥavitz</i></b> cooked in a <b>pot. Rav Yehuda said</b> that one recites: By Whose word <b>all things</b> came to be, as he <b>held that the honey is primary,</b> and on honey one recites: By Whose word all things came to be. <b>Rav Kahana said</b> that one recites: <b>Who creates the various kinds of nourishment,</b> as <b>he held that the flour,</b> as is the case with all products produced from grain, <b>is primary,</b> and therefore one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. <b>Rav Yosef said: It is reasonable</b> to say <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Kahana, as Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that has of the five species</b> of grain <b>in it, one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment,</b> even if it is mixed with other ingredients.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> of the blessing recited over the five species of grain, the Gemara clarifies <b>the matter itself. Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that has of the five species</b> of grain <b>in it, one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b> Elsewhere, <b>it was stated</b> that <b>Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that is from the five species</b> of grain, <b>one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b> This is problematic, as these statements appear redundant.
The Gemara explains: Both statements are <b>necessary,</b> as <b>had he taught us</b> only: <b>Anything that is</b> from the five species of grain, one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, <b>I would have said</b> that is <b>because</b> the grain <b>is in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, <b>but</b> if one eats it <b>in</b> the context of <b>a mixture, no,</b> one does not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.

Daf 37a

Therefore, <b>he teaches us: Anything that has</b> of the five species of grain <b>in it,</b> even if it is in the context of a mixture with other ingredients. <b>And had he taught us</b> only: <b>Anything that has</b> of the five species of grain <b>in it, I would have said</b> that specifically over <b>anything that has</b> of the five species of grain <b>in it, yes,</b> one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, even if it is in the context of a mixture with other ingredients. <b>However,</b> over anything that has <b>rice and millet</b> in it, <b>no,</b> one does not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, <b>because</b> one is eating <b>it in</b> the context of <b>a mixture. However,</b> if the rice or millet <b>is in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, <b>say</b> that <b>even over rice and millet one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment,</b> because they, too, are types of grain. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> specifically: <b>Anything that is from the five species</b> of grain, <b>one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, to the exclusion of rice and millet,</b> over <b>which, even in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, <b>one does not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b>
With regard to the previous conclusion, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> over <b>rice and millet we do not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If they brought before him rice bread or millet bread, he recites the blessing over it</b> both <b>before and after, as</b> he would recite the blessing over <b>a cooked dish</b> containing dough from the five species of the grain. <b>And with regard to a cooked dish, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>At the start, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end, one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals [<i>al hamiḥya</i>]. Apparently, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, over rice and millet.
The Gemara rejects this proof: Indeed, rice or millet is <b>like a cooked dish, and is not like a cooked dish</b> in every sense. The Gemara elaborates: It is considered <b>like a cooked dish</b> in that <b>one recites a blessing over it</b> both at the <b>beginning and</b> the <b>end. And it is unlike a cooked dish</b> in that <b>over a cooked dish, at the start, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end,</b> one recites <b>one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals; <b>whereas here, over</b> rice, <b>at the start, one recites: By Whose word all things came to be, and at the end,</b> one recites: <b>Who creates the many forms of life and their needs for all that You have created.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And rice is not a cooked dish? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>these are cooked dishes: Wheat kernels split into two parts, wheat kernels crushed into three parts [<i>teraggis</i>], flour, wheat kernels crushed into four parts [<i>zariz</i>], wheat kernels crushed into five parts [<i>arsan</i>] and rice?</b> Apparently, rice is considered a cooked dish like crushed wheat.
The Gemara responds: <b>Whose</b> opinion is reflected in <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri’s</b> opinion, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: Rice is a type of grain</b> in every respect and, therefore, <b>one is liable to</b> death by <b><i>karet</i> if it leavens</b> on Passover and he eats it intentionally. <b>And a person</b> who ate <i>matza</i> baked from rice flour <b>fulfills his obligation on Passover; however,</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, no,</b> rice is not in the category of a cooked dish.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>And the Rabbis</b> hold that rice is <b>not</b> considered a cooked dish? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who chews wheat recites: Who creates fruit of the ground.</b> However, if <b>he ground</b> the wheat, <b>baked it, and cooked</b> the bread, there is a distinction between two situations: <b>When the slices are intact</b> and did not dissolve in the boiling process, <b>at the start one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth, and at the end one recites</b> the <b>three blessings</b> of Grace after Meals, as he does after eating bread. <b>When the slices</b> dissolved in the course of the boiling process and <b>are not intact,</b> then <b>at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals.
<b>One who chews rice recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. If one ground it, baked it, and then cooked it, even though the pieces are intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals.
The Gemara discusses this <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Whose</b> opinion is reflected in <b>this</b> <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>If you say that</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri who said</b> that <b>rice is a type of grain,</b> it should have said that one must recite: <b>Who brings forth bread from the earth,</b> beforehand <b>and</b> the <b>three blessings</b> of Grace after Meals thereafter, as he does after eating bread.
<b>Rather, isn’t it</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that rice is not a type of grain, but nevertheless hold that over rice one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment? If so, this is a <b>conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav and Shmuel.</b>
The Gemara comments: Indeed, this <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of their opinion.
Above, it was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>the Master said: One who chews wheat recites: Who creates fruit of the ground.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that one who chews wheat recites: <b>Who creates various kinds of seeds?</b> The Gemara resolves the problem: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as it is the subject of a tannaitic dispute. <b>This</b> opinion, that one must recite: Who creates various kinds of seeds, is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and this</b> opinion, that one must recite: Who creates fruit of the ground, is the opinion of the <b>Rabbis. As we learned</b> in our mishna: <b>Over</b> herbs and leafy <b>vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Rabbi Yehuda says: Who creates various kinds of herbs.</b> Rabbi Yehuda designates specific blessings for every type of plant, and he certainly distinguishes between vegetables in general and seeds.
It was taught in the same <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>the Master said: One who chews rice recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. If one ground it, baked it and then cooked it, even though the pieces are intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals.
The Gemara raises the challenge: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in that case, <b>at the end</b> one need <b>not</b> recite <b>any</b> of the blessings recited over the fruits of Eretz Yisrael, but rather: Who creates the many forms of life. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as this is the subject of a tannaitic dispute. <b>This,</b> that one recites one blessing abridged from the three blessings of Grace after Meals, is the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel. This,</b> that one need only recite: Who creates the many forms of life, is the opinion of the <b>Rabbis. As it was taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>this is the principle: Anything that is from the seven species</b> of grain and fruits for which Eretz Yisrael is praised, <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> Afterwards, one recites the <b>three blessings</b> of the Grace after Meals. <b>And the Rabbis say: One blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals is sufficient.
The Gemara relates: <b>And</b> there was an <b>incident involving Rabban Gamliel and the Sages who were sitting in an upper floor in Jericho and they brought dates before them and they ate. And</b> afterwards, <b>Rabban Gamliel gave Rabbi Akiva permission to recite the blessing. Rabbi Akiva hurried and recited one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals. <b>Rabban Gamliel said: Akiva, until when will you</b> continue to <b>stick your head into the dispute</b> among the Sages with regard to what you did? Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him: Our teacher, even though you say this while your colleagues</b> disagree and <b>say that, you taught us, our teacher,</b> the general principle that guides resolution of halakhic disputes: In a dispute between <b>an individual and the many, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the many.</b> Although you are the <i>Nasi</i>, it is appropriate to act in accordance with the opinion of the many.
The Gemara records a variation on the dispute between Rabban Gamliel and the Rabbis: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says in his name,</b> the name of Rabbi Akiva. With regard to <b>anything that is from the seven species</b>

Daf 37b

<b>and is not a species of grain,</b> but one of the fruits, <b>or which is a species of grain and has not been made into bread,</b> there is a dispute. <b>Rabban Gamliel says</b> that one recites the <b>three blessings</b> of the Grace after Meals <b>and the Rabbis say</b> that one recites <b>a single blessing. And</b> over <b>anything that is neither one of the seven species nor a species of grain, such as rice bread or millet bread, Rabban Gamliel says</b> that after eating, one recites <b>one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals, <b>and the Rabbis say</b> that one need <b>not</b> recite <b>any</b> blessing, i.e., Grace after Meals or one blessing abridged from three, but instead he recites: Who creates the many forms of life. If so, the <i>Tosefta</i>, which says that after rice one recites one blessing abridged from three, is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda’s version of Rabban Gamliel’s opinion.
The Gemara challenges: <b>How did you establish</b> the <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel. Say the latter clause of the first</b> section of this <i>Tosefta</i>, which states that even over wheat bread, <b>when the slices are not intact,</b> then <b>at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals. <b>Whose</b> opinion is reflected in that section of the <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>If</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, now</b> if over <b>dates and pounded wheat, Rabban Gamliel said</b> that one recites the <b>three blessings</b> of Grace after Meals, in a case <b>where the slices</b> of bread <b>are not intact, is it necessary</b> to say that one recites Grace after Meals?
<b>Rather, it is clear</b> that the <i>Tosefta</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. If so, there is a contradiction between</b> one opinion of <b>the Rabbis and</b> a second opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara resolves the contradiction: <b>Rather, actually,</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and</b> emend the text <b>and teach with regard to rice: At the end, one does not recite any blessing,</b> consistent with their opinion in the <i>baraita</i>.
With regard to the blessings recited over various types of porridge, <b>Rava said:</b> Over <b>the farmer’s mixture of flour and honey to which they add</b> extra <b>flour, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. What is the reason?</b> Because <b>the flour is</b> the <b>primary</b> ingredient in the mixture. Over this same dish, however, when it is prepared in the manner that it is prepared in <b>Meḥoza</b> where <b>they do not add</b> extra <b>flour, one recites: By Whose word all things came to be. What is the reason?</b> Because in that dish, <b>the honey is</b> the <b>primary</b> ingredient. <b>And Rava reconsidered and said:</b> Over <b>both this,</b> the mixture of the farmers, and <b>that,</b> the mixture of Meḥoza, one recites: <b>Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. As Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that is from the five species</b> of grain, <b>one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Over <b>this cooked dish, which contains pieces</b> of bread that are the size of <b>an olive-bulk, at the start one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth, and afterward one recites</b> the <b>three blessings</b> of Grace after Meals as he would over bread. Over that same cooked dish, <b>which does not contain pieces</b> of bread that are the size of <b>an olive-bulk, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals, as he would over a cooked dish.
<b>And Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The first time the priest <b>would stand and offer meal-offerings in Jerusalem, he would recite: Who has given us life, sustained us, and brought us to this time,</b> as it is the first time that he fulfilled the mitzva of offering that sacrifice (Rashi). <b>When he would take</b> the meal-offerings in order <b>to eat them, he would recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth. And it was taught on the</b> topic of meal-offerings: <b>And all of the</b> meal-offerings, <b>he crumbles</b> them into pieces, approximately the size of an <b>olive-bulk.</b> This proves that over bread crumbs the size of an olive-bulk, one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>But</b> if what you say is <b>so, then now, according to the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael</b> who <b>said</b> with regard to meal-offerings: <b>He crushes them until he restores them to</b> the form that they were when <b>they were flour,</b> would you say that <b>so too,</b> in that case, <b>he need not recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth? And if you say</b> that <b>that is so,</b> that one does not recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth, over these meal-offerings, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who gathered an olive-bulk</b> sized portion <b>from all of</b> the crumbs of the meal-offerings <b>and ate them, if it was</b> an offering of <b>leavened bread</b> like that of a thanks-offering, if he ate them on Passover he is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>. If</b> it was an offering <b>of unleavened bread, one fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover.</b> This illustrates that bread crumbs, regardless of their size, are always considered bread.
Rav Yosef answered that this is not the case, and one does not recite a blessing over bread crumbs as he would over actual bread. Rather, <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where</b> one mixed the bread crumbs with water <b>and compacted them</b> into a single mass. The Gemara challenges this: <b>If so, say the latter clause,</b> in which we learn that <b>this case</b> of one who eats the crumbs speaks specifically about <b>when he ate them,</b> all of the crumbs that constitute the size of an olive-bulk <b>in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf of bread. And if</b> it is referring to a case where <b>one compacted them</b> into a single mass, <b>that</b> expression: <b>When he ate them,</b> is inappropriate. <b>When he ate it, is what it needed</b> to say, as it is a single loaf.
<b>Rather,</b> it can be explained in another way: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where</b> each of the crumbs <b>came from a large</b> loaf of <b>bread</b> over which one is obligated to recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth. Over crumbs that were never part of a loaf of bread large enough to require this blessing, however, one need only recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth, if they are at least the size of an olive-bulk.
Since all of the proofs for and against this opinion were rejected, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> Over <b>this cooked dish, which contains</b> bread <b>crumbs, even though it does not contain crumbs</b> the size <b>of an olive-bulk, one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth. Rava said: This is</b> specifically in a case where the crumbs still <b>have the appearance of bread</b> and did not dissolve completely.
Another issue concerned <b><i>terokanin</i>,</b> with regard to which it was said that <b>they are obligated in</b> the mitzva to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> meaning that <i>terokanin</i> have the halakhic status of bread. <b>And, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: <i>Terokanin</i> are exempt from</b> the mitzva to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are <i>terokanin</i>? Abaye said:</b> <i>Terokanin</i> are made of a watery mixture of flour and water roasted in a <b>cavity</b> in a stove <b>in the ground</b> and is not actually bread.
<b>And Abaye said: <i>Terita</i> is exempt from</b> the mitzva to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is <b><i>terita</i>?</b> There are several opinions: <b>Some say,</b> it is flour and water <b>kneaded</b> that is poured onto a <b>boiling</b> hot stove. <b>And some say,</b> it is <b>bread from India,</b> made from dough wrapped around a skewer and covered with oil or eggs before baking. <b>And some say,</b> it is <b>bread made for <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> bread baked in an unusual manner so that it would become extremely leavened and could be used as an ingredient in the Babylonian spice, <i>kutaḥ</i>.
And similarly, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: Bread made for <i>kutaḥ</i>;</b> one <b>is exempt from</b> the mitzva to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that one <b>is obligated in</b> the mitzva to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from bread made for <i>kutaḥ</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>There, as the reason was taught</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> There is a distinction between different types of bread made for <i>kutaḥ</i>, as <b>the actions</b> taken in <b>its</b> preparation <b>prove</b> the purpose for which <b>it</b> was made. <b>If he made them</b>

Daf 38a

<b>thick [<i>ke’avin</i>],</b> so that they appear like loaves of bread, <b>they are obligated</b> in <i>ḥalla</i>, and if he shaped them <b>like boards [<i>kelimmudin</i>], they are exempt,</b> since they will certainly only be used for <i>kutaḥ</i>. <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What blessing is recited over the dough of the ground?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Do you think that it is bread? It is merely kneaded</b> dough, <b>and</b> just like over all other cooked grains, <b>one recites over it the blessing: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra based his meal on this</b> dough, and <b>he recited: Who brings forth bread from the earth,</b> beforehand and the <b>three blessings</b> of Grace after Meals thereafter. Since he based his meal on it, he considered it to be bread.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said:</b> With these types of bread, <b>a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover. What is the reason?</b> Because <b>we call it bread of affliction,</b> and in that sense, it is in the category of <i>matza</i>.
<b>And</b> with regard to blessings, <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Over this date honey one recites: By Whose word all things came to be. What is the reason</b> that one does not recite: Who creates fruit of the tree, as he does over the date itself? Because date honey is not the essence of the fruit, but <b>merely moisture</b> that drips from the ripe fruit.
<b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion does he recite that blessing? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna: If a non-priest ate <b>date honey, apple wine or vinegar made from grapes of autumn</b> that grow stunted at the end of the season and are unfit for wine production, <b>or</b> any <b>other</b> type of <b>juice</b> made <b>from fruits of <i>teruma</i>, Rabbi Eliezer obligates</b> him to repay <b>the principal and</b> an additional <b>fifth</b> as a penalty for misuse of consecrated items. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him from payment, because he holds that these are byproducts of the fruit and do not have the status of the fruit itself. Mar bar Rav Ashi’s ruling with regard to blessings was based on Rabbi Yehoshua’s ruling with regard to <i>teruma</i>.
<b>One of the Sages said to Rava: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>terima</i>? Rava</b> was unfamiliar with the term <i>terima</i> and <b>did not understand what he was saying to him. Ravina sat before Rava</b> and <b>said to</b> the student who had posed the question to Rava: In posing the question, are <b>you speaking of sesame</b> <i>terima</i> <b>or</b> are <b>you speaking of safflower</b> <i>terima</i> <b>or</b> are <b>you speaking of grape-pits</b> <i>terima</i>?
<b>Meanwhile, Rava comprehended</b> the meaning of the term <b>and said to</b> the Sage: <b>Certainly, you are speaking of pressed</b> items, <b>and you reminded me of a matter that Rav Asi said: Those dates of <i>teruma</i>; one is permitted</b> to press them in order <b>to make <i>terima</i>,</b> because the dates maintain their form, <b>and one is forbidden to make</b> date <b>beer</b> from them, as in so doing the dates are damaged and it is forbidden to damage <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara concludes: The <i>halakha</i> is that <b>over dates</b> that were <b>made into <i>terima</i>, one recites: Who creates fruit of the tree. What is the reason?</b> Because <b>they remain in their original state.</b>
The Gemara raises another question with regard to the blessing recited on <b>roasted barley to which honey or vinegar was added [<i>shetita</i>]. Rav said</b> that one recites: <b>By Whose word all things came to be; and Shmuel said</b> that one recites: <b>Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: And they do not disagree,</b> as each is referring to a different case. <b>This,</b> where Shmuel said that one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, <b>is in</b> a case where the mixture is <b>thick,</b> while <b>this,</b> where Rav said that one recites: By Whose word all things came to be, <b>is in</b> a case where the mixture is <b>thin.</b> When it is <b>thick, he made it as food;</b> therefore one recites a blessing just as he would over any food made from the five species of grain. When it is <b>thin, he made it as medicine,</b> therefore one only recites: By Whose word all things came to be.
With regard to the assumption that this mixture is essentially medicinal, <b>Rav Yosef raised a challenge</b> from the laws of Shabbat: <b>And they agree that one may mix <i>shetita</i> on Shabbat and drink Egyptian beer [<i>zitom haMitzri</i>],</b> which contains a mixture of a pungent spice in flour. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that when one prepares <i>shetita</i>, <b>his intention is for medicinal</b> purposes, <b>is medicine permitted on Shabbat?</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Do you not hold</b> that to be true? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>All foods</b> that are commonly eaten; <b>a person may eat</b> them <b>for medicinal</b> purposes <b>on Shabbat, and all drinks</b> that are not designated for medicinal purposes, a person may <b>drink</b> them for medicinal purposes on Shabbat. <b>But what can you say</b> in explaining that ruling? <b>The man’s intention is</b> for the purpose of <b>eating;</b> here <b>too,</b> when he mixes the <i>shetita</i>, <b>the man’s intention is</b> for the purpose of <b>eating.</b>
The Gemara cites <b>another version</b> of what was taught above: <b>But what can you say</b> in explaining that ruling? <b>The man’s intention is for</b> the purpose of <b>eating and the cure comes about on its own;</b> here <b>too, the man’s intention is for</b> the purpose of <b>eating and the cure comes about on its own.</b> Ostensibly, after proving that it is permissible to drink the <i>shetita</i> on Shabbat, it is clearly a type of food over which one is required to recite a blessing. If so, it is difficult to understand the need for Rav and Shmuel to point out that one is required to recite a blessing over it.
Therefore the Gemara says: <b>And</b> the statement <b>of Rav and Shmuel is necessary, as if</b> the <i>halakha</i> had been derived solely <b>from this</b> mishna that permits drinking <i>shetita</i> on Shabbat, <b>I would have said:</b> This applies specifically when <b>one’s intention is for</b> the purpose of <b>eating and the cure comes about on its own. Here, however, since from the outset, his intention</b> in eating the <i>shetita</i> <b>is for</b> the purpose of <b>medicine;</b> just as one recites no blessing when he ingests medicine, <b>let him recite no blessing over</b> the <i>shetita</i> <b>at all.</b> Therefore, Rav and Shmuel <b>taught us</b> that here, <b>since he derives pleasure from</b> eating <b>it,</b> he <b>is required to recite a blessing.</b>
We learned in the mishna <b>that over bread one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What does</b> one who eats bread <b>recite</b> before eating? <b>Who brings forth [<i>hamotzi</i>] bread from the earth. Rabbi Neḥemya says</b> that the blessing is phrased: <b>Who brought forth [<i>motzi</i>] bread from the earth. Rava said: Everyone agrees that</b> the term <b><i>motzi</i> means brought,</b> in the past tense, <b>as it is written: “God who brought them forth [<i>motziam</i>] from Egypt</b> is for them like the horns of the wild ox” (Numbers 23:22). <b>When do they disagree? With regard to</b> the term <b><i>hamotzi</i>, as the Rabbis hold</b> that <b><i>hamotzi</i> means</b> that God <b>brought forth,</b> in the past tense, <b>as it is written: “Who brought forth [<i>hamotzi</i>] for you water from a rock of flint”</b> (Deuteronomy 8:15), which depicts a past event. <b>Rabbi Neḥemya holds</b> that the term <b><i>hamotzi</i> means</b> that God <b>brings forth</b> in the present tense, <b>as it is stated</b> in Moses’ prophecy to the Jewish people in Egypt: “And you will know that I am the Lord your God <b>who is bringing you forth [<i>hamotzi</i>] from under the burdens of Egypt”</b> (Exodus 6:7). Since, in that context, <i>hamotzi</i> is used with regard to an event transpiring in the present or possibly even one that will transpire in the future, it is inappropriate to include this term in a blessing referencing the past.
<b>And the Rabbis,</b> how do they respond to that proof? The Sages interpret <b>that</b> verse to mean that <b>the Holy one, Blessed be He, said to Israel as follows: When I bring you forth, I will perform something for you that you will know that I am the one who brought you forth from Egypt, as it is written: “And you will know that I am the Lord your God who brought you forth [<i>hamotzi</i>]”;</b> in this verse, too, <i>hamotzi</i> refers to the past.
On that note, the Gemara relates: <b>The Sages would praise son of Rav Zevid, brother of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Zevid to Rabbi Zeira, that he is a great man and he is expert in blessings.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> the Sages: <b>When he comes to you, bring him to me</b> so that I can meet him. <b>One day he happened</b> to come <b>before him. They brought out bread</b> to the guest, <b>he began and recited: Who brought forth [<i>motzi</i>] bread from the earth.</b> Rabbi Zeira grew annoyed <b>and said: This is he of whom they say that he is a great man and expert in blessings? Granted, had he recited: <i>Hamotzi,</i></b>

Daf 38b

I would have understood that <b>he</b> thereby <b>taught us the meaning</b> of the verse: “Who brought you forth from Egypt,” <b>and he</b> thereby <b>taught us that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. However, what did he teach us by reciting <i>motzi</i>?</b> Everyone agrees that one fulfills his obligation when reciting <i>motzi</i>. The Gemara explains: The son of Rav Zevid <b>did this</b> in order <b>to preclude himself from</b> taking sides in <b>the dispute.</b> He preferred to phrase his blessing in a manner appropriate according to all opinions, rather than teach a novel concept, which is not universally accepted.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that one recites: <b>Who brings forth [<i>hamotzi</i>] bread from the earth, as we hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis who say</b> that it also means: Who brought forth.
We learned in the mishna that <b>over vegetables one recites:</b> Who creates fruits of the ground. The Gemara comments: The mishna <b>taught vegetables</b> together with, and therefore <b>similar to, bread,</b> and from this analogy one may infer: <b>Just as bread</b> is food <b>that was transformed by fire, so too vegetables</b> retain the blessing: Who creates fruits of the ground, after they <b>have been transformed by fire. Rabbenai said in the name</b> of <b>Abaye: This means</b> that <b>over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruits of the ground. From where</b> is this matter inferred? From the fact that the mishna <b>taught vegetables similar to bread.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda taught in the name of Rabbeinu; and</b> the Gemara remarks incidentally: <b>Who is</b> Rabbeinu? <b>Rav. Over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. And our Rabbis who descended from Eretz Yisrael,</b> and again the Gemara explains: <b>And who is</b> the Sage with this title? <b>Ulla said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Over boiled vegetables one recites: By whose word all things came to be,</b> since after they are boiled, they are no longer the same as they were before. Expressing his own opinion, Rav Ḥisda said: <b>And I say</b> that there is an intermediate opinion: <b>Any</b> vegetable that, when eaten <b>in its original</b> uncooked state, one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> when he <b>boiled it,</b> he recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be,</b> as boiling damages it qualitatively. <b>And any</b> vegetable that when eaten <b>in its original</b> uncooked state, one recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be,</b> because it is not typically eaten raw, when he <b>boiled it,</b> he recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, any</b> vegetable that, when eaten <b>in its original</b> uncooked state, one recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be,</b> when he <b>boiled it,</b> he recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> as <b>you</b> can <b>find</b> several vegetables, e.g., <b>cabbage, chard, and pumpkin</b> which are virtually inedible raw, and boiling renders it edible. <b>However,</b> under <b>what</b> circumstances can <b>you find</b> a case where <b>any</b> vegetable that when eaten <b>in its original</b> uncooked state, one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> when he <b>boiled it,</b> he recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be,</b> as boiling damages the vegetable qualitatively? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: You</b> can <b>find it</b> in the case of <b>garlic and leeks.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman taught in the name of Rabbeinu; and who is</b> Rabbeinu? <b>Shmuel: Over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. And our colleagues who descended from Eretz Yisrael; and who is</b> the Sage with this title? <b>Ulla said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: By whose word all things came to be.</b>
Rav Naḥman remarked: <b>I say this</b> is dependent upon and <b>taught as a</b> tannaitic <b>dispute, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>matza</i> on Passover: <b>One fulfills the</b> mitzva of <i>matza</i> <b>with a wafer soaked</b> in water or <b>with</b> one that is <b>boiled</b> as long that <b>it did not dissolve;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yosei says: One fulfills the</b> mitzva of <i>matza</i> <b>with a soaked wafer but not with</b> one that is <b>boiled even if it did not dissolve.</b> Rav Naḥman concludes that this dispute with regard to boiled <i>matza</i> reflects a larger dispute with regard to boiling in general, whether or not it diminishes the flavor of that which is boiled.
This approach is rejected by the Gemara: <b>That is not so; as everyone agrees that over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Rabbi Yosei only said</b> the <i>halakha</i>, that one fulfills his obligation of <i>matza</i> if it is soaked but not if it is boiled, <b>there, because</b> in order to fulfill the mitzva, <b>we require</b> the <b>taste of <i>matza</i>, and it is lacking. However, here, even Rabbi Yosei agrees</b> that boiling vegetables does not damage it qualitatively.
Ulla’s statement in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to boiled vegetables was cited above. The Gemara cites two conflicting traditions with regard to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground, and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: By whose word all things came to be.</b> Commenting on this, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Ulla established his error in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet,</b> which conflicted with the prevailing opinion among the Sages in Babylonia.
<b>Rabbi Zeira wondered</b> with regard to Ulla’s approach: <b>What is the matter of Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet</b> doing in the same discussion <b>with Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was meticulous and learned the <i>halakha</i> from Rabbi Yoḥanan, his teacher; and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet was not meticulous. Furthermore, every thirty days, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba reviews his studies before Rabbi Yoḥanan, his teacher, while Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet does not review</b> his studies. <b>Furthermore, aside from these</b> reasons concerning the difference between a wise and meticulous student like Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba and a student like Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet, one can also bring proof from the custom of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as <b>the lupin is boiled seven times in a pot and eaten as dessert</b> at the end of a <b>meal. They came and asked Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> with regard to the blessing to be recited over this lupin, <b>and he said to them: One recites over it: Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> indicating that one recites that blessing over boiled vegetables.
<b>Furthermore, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: I saw Rabbi Yoḥanan eat a salted olive,</b> which, halakhically, is considered cooked, <b>and he recited a blessing over it both before and after. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>boiled vegetables remain in their original state</b> and that cooking does not qualitatively damage them, then certainly <b>at the start one recites over it: Who creates fruit of the tree, and at the end one recites over it one blessing abridged from</b> the <b>three</b> blessings of Grace after Meals, just as he would over any of the seven species for which Eretz Yisrael was praised. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>boiled vegetables do not remain in their original state, granted, at the start, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. However, at the end, what blessing does he recite?</b> There are several opinions that hold that no blessing is recited after eating something whose initial blessing was: By whose word all things came to be.
The Gemara rejects this: That is no proof, as <b>perhaps</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan held that on items over which at the start one recites: By whose word all things came to be, at the end he recites: <b>Who creates the many forms of life and their needs, for all that You have created.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Shmuel raised an objection</b> to the ruling that over both boiled vegetables and raw vegetables one recites the same blessing, from a <i>baraita</i> concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of eating bitter herbs on Passover: <b>Vegetables with which one may fulfill his obligation</b> in the mitzva of bitter herbs <b>on Passover, one fulfills</b> his obligation <b>with</b> both the vegetables <b>themselves as well as with their stalks. However,</b> one may <b>neither</b> fulfill his obligation <b>with pickled</b> vegetables, <b>nor with boiled</b> vegetables <b>nor with cooked</b> vegetables. <b>And if it would enter your mind</b> that <b>they remain in their original state, why are boiled</b> vegetables not fit for use in fulfilling the mitzva of bitter herbs?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as</b> even if we assert that boiled vegetables remain in their original state, <b>we require</b> the <b>taste of bitter herbs, and it is lacking.</b> There is no proof that boiling damages the vegetable qualitatively.
The Gemara related above that Rabbi Yoḥanan recited a blessing over a salted olive. With regard to this story, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: How did Rabbi Yoḥanan recite a blessing over a salted olive</b> after he ate it? <b>Since the pit was removed,</b> i.e., he did not eat it,

Daf 39a

<b>it lacks the</b> requisite <b>measure?</b> The smallest quantity of food that is considered eating is the size of an olive-bulk, and an olive with its pit removed is smaller than that.
<b>He said to him: Do you hold that we require a large olive</b> as the measure of food necessary in order to recite a blessing after eating? <b>We require a medium-sized olive and that</b> olive <b>was</b> that size, as the olive <b>that they brought before Rabbi Yoḥanan was a large olive. Even though they removed its pit, the</b> requisite <b>measure remained.</b>
The Gemara cites a proof that the halakhic measure of an olive is not based on a large olive <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The olive of which</b> the Sages <b>spoke</b> with regard to the halakhic measures is <b>neither small nor large, but medium, and that</b> olive <b>is</b> called <b><i>aguri</i>. And Rabbi Abbahu said: The name</b> of that genus of olives <b>is not <i>aguri</i>, but its name is <i>avruti</i>, and some say</b> that <b>its name is <i>samrusi</i>. And why,</b> then, <b>is it called <i>aguri</i>? Because its oil is accumulated [<i>agur</i>] inside it.</b>
With regard to the appropriate blessing over boiled vegetables: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute <b>is parallel</b> to a dispute between the <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as the Gemara relates: <b>Two students were sitting before bar Kappara when</b> cooked <b>cabbage,</b> cooked Damascene <b>plums and pullets were set before him. Bar Kappara gave one of</b> the students <b>permission to recite a blessing. He hurried and recited a blessing over the pullets</b> and <b>his counterpart ridiculed him</b> for gluttonously reciting the blessing that should have been recited later, first. <b>Bar Kappara became angry</b> with both of them, <b>he said: I am not angry with the one who recited the blessing, but at the one who ridiculed</b> him. <b>If your counterpart is like one who never tasted the flavor of meat</b> and was therefore partial to the pullet, and hurriedly ate it, <b>why did you ridicule him?</b> Bar Kappara <b>continued and said</b> to the second student: <b>I am not upset at the one who ridiculed</b> him, <b>rather</b> it is <b>with the one who recited the blessing that I am angry. And he said: If there is no wisdom here, is there no elder here?</b> If you are uncertain which blessing to recite first, couldn’t you have asked me, as I am an elder?
The Gemara concludes that <b>it was taught: And both of them did not</b> live <b>out his year.</b> Due to bar Kappara’s anger they were punished, and both died within the year.
The Gemara attempts to infer from this story to the topic at hand: <b>What? Is it not that they disagreed with regard to the following?</b> The <b>one who recited the blessing</b> over the pullet first <b>held</b> that the blessing to be recited over both <b>boiled vegetables and pullet</b> is: <b>By whose word all things came to be, and, therefore,</b> that which <b>he prefers</b> takes <b>precedence</b> and is eaten first. The <b>one who ridiculed</b> him <b>held</b> that over <b>boiled vegetables</b> one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> and over <b>pullet</b> one recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be, and, therefore, the fruit</b> takes <b>precedence,</b> as its blessing is more specific and therefore more significant.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that over <b>boiled vegetables and pullet</b> one recites: <b>By whose word all things came to be, and here they argue over this:</b> This <b>Sage,</b> who recited the blessing, <b>held that</b> the food which is <b>preferred takes precedence</b> and one recites a blessing over it first, <b>and the Sage</b> who ridiculed him <b>held: Cabbage takes precedence, as it nourishes.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Huna he said to us: These turnip heads,</b> if <b>one cut them</b> into <b>large</b> slices, he recites over them: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground,</b> because in doing so he has not significantly changed them. If he <b>cut them</b> into <b>small</b> pieces, he recites over them: <b>By whose word all things came to be. And when we came to the study hall of Rav Yehuda he said to us:</b> Over both <b>these,</b> large slices, <b>and those,</b> small pieces, one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground, and the fact that he cut them extensively was in order to sweeten its flavor.</b>
On a similar note, <b>Rav Ashi said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, he said to us:</b> Over <b>a cooked dish of beets to which they,</b> typically, <b>do not add</b> a <b>significant</b> amount of <b>flour,</b> one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground.</b> Over <b>a cooked dish of turnips to which they,</b> typically, <b>add</b> a <b>more significant</b> amount of <b>flour,</b> one recites: <b>Who creates the various types of nourishment. And</b> Rav Kahana <b>reconsidered</b> his previous statement and said: Over both <b>these,</b> beets, <b>and those,</b> turnips, one recites: <b>Who creates fruit of the ground, and the fact that they threw extra flour in</b> with the turnips, <b>they did so merely</b> so the components of the cooked dish would <b>stick together.</b> The primary ingredient in the dish remains the turnips, not the flour.
Tangential to this mention of a turnip dish, <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> added, <b>and said: A cooked dish of beets is beneficial for the heart, good for the eyes and all the more so, for the intestines. Abaye said: That is</b> specifically when the dish <b>sits on the stove and makes a <i>tukh tukh</i></b> sound, i.e., it boils.
<b>Rav Pappa said: It is clear to me</b> that <b>beet water,</b> water in which beets were boiled, <b>has</b> the same status <b>as beets, and turnip water has</b> the same status <b>turnips, and the water</b> in which <b>all boiled vegetables</b> were boiled <b>has</b> the same status <b>as all boiled vegetables.</b> However, <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What</b> is the status of <b>water</b> in which <b>dill</b> was boiled? <b>Do they use</b> dill <b>to sweeten the taste, or do they use it to remove</b> residual <b>filth?</b> If the dill was added to flavor the food then the water in which it was boiled should be treated like water in which any other vegetable was boiled. However, if the dill was added merely to absorb the residue of the soup, then there was never any intention to flavor the dish and one should not recite a blessing over it.
<b>Come and hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from what we learned in a mishna in the tractate <i>Okatzin</i>: <b>Dill, once it has</b> already <b>given</b> its <b>flavor in the pot,</b> no longer has any value and <b>is no</b> longer <b>subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> since it is no longer considered food, <b>it can no</b> longer become impure with <b>the ritual impurity of food. Learn from this</b> that <b>they used</b> dill <b>to sweeten the taste.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: Over dry bread</b> that was placed <b>in a bowl</b> to soak, <b>one recites: Who brings forth</b> bread from the earth, even if there is another loaf of bread before him, as it is considered bread in every respect. This <i>halakha</i> <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya said: The blessing must conclude with</b> the beginning of the breaking of <b>the</b> loaf of <b>bread.</b> The dried bread had already been sliced and separated from the loaf.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this</b> assumption: <b>What is different about dried bread, that</b> one does <b>not</b> recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth, over it, <b>because when the blessing concludes, it concludes on a slice?</b> In a case where he recites a blessing <b>on</b> a loaf of <b>bread as well, when he completes</b> the blessing, <b>he completes it on a slice,</b> as one cuts the bread before the blessing.

Daf 39b

<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> When breaking bread, one <b>recites the blessing</b> over the complete loaf <b>and</b> only <b>afterwards, he breaks it.</b>
The Gemara relates: The Sages <b>of Neharde’a acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> and would recite the blessing as they were breaking the bread and conclude the blessing as he finished breaking off the piece of bread. <b>And the Rabbis acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> and would recite the blessing before breaking the bread. <b>Ravina said: My mother told me: Your father acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya said: The blessing must conclude with</b> the beginning of the breaking of <b>the</b> loaf of <b>bread. And the Rabbis acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> who <b>said</b> one <b>recites the blessing</b> over the complete loaf <b>and</b> only <b>afterwards he breaks it.</b>
<b>It was stated</b> that there was an amoraic dispute with regard to whether to recite the blessing over a whole loaf of bread or to recite it over a piece of bread: If <b>they brought pieces and whole</b> loaves of bread <b>before</b> those partaking of a meal, <b>Rav Huna said: One</b> may <b>recite the blessing over the pieces and</b> with that blessing <b>exempts the whole</b> loaves as well. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The optimal manner</b> in which to fulfill <b>the mitzva</b> is to recite the blessing over the <b>whole</b> loaf. <b>However,</b> if the <b>piece was of wheat</b> bread <b>and the whole</b> loaf <b>was of barley</b> bread, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>one recites a blessing over the piece of wheat</b> bread. Although it is a piece of bread, it is nevertheless of superior quality, <b>and</b> in so doing <b>one exempts the whole</b> loaf <b>of barley</b> bread.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that the dispute between Rav Huna and Rabbi Yoḥanan is <b>parallel</b> to a <b>tannaitic</b> dispute with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i>. We learned: Even though the onions from which the <i>teruma</i> must be separated are divided equally between the two, <b>one separates <i>teruma</i> from a whole small onion but not from half of a large onion. Rabbi Yehuda says: No, rather,</b> he separates <i>teruma</i> from <b>half of a large onion. What, is it not that they disagree over this</b> point, <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>held</b> that the <b>more significant takes precedence;</b> therefore half of a large onion which is of superior quality is preferable, <b>and</b> the first <i>tanna</i> <b>held</b> that the <b>whole</b> item <b>takes precedence?</b>
The Gemara rejects this comparison: <b>Where there is a priest</b> who can immediately take the <i>teruma</i> from him, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>more significant takes precedence. When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>where there is no priest</b> there, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Everywhere that there is a priest, one separates <i>teruma</i> from the best, and whenever there is no priest, one separates <i>teruma</i> from that which will endure,</b> so that when a priest ultimately receives it, he will be able to derive benefit from it. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> always <b>separates <i>teruma</i> only from the best,</b> even though it is not the longest-lasting.
With regard to the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rav Huna, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: A God-fearing individual fulfills both. And who is this</b> God-fearing person? <b>Mar, son of Ravina,</b> as the Gemara relates that <b>Mar, son of Ravina,</b> would <b>place the piece inside the</b> whole <b>loaf and break</b> them together.
Similarly, the Gemara relates that <b>the <i>tanna</i> recited</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: One places the piece inside the whole</b> loaf, then <b>breaks</b> the bread <b>and recites a blessing.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: What is your name? He answered: Shalman.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>replied</b> with a pun: <b>You are peace [<i>shalom</i>] and</b> the <b>teaching</b> that <b>you</b> recited <b>is complete [<i>shelema</i>] as</b> by means of this <i>baraita</i> the disputing opinions are reconciled and <b>you established peace among students.</b>
This resolution is reinforced in a unique case, as <b>Rav Pappa said: Everyone agrees that</b> while fulfilling the mitzva of eating <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover, one places the piece inside the whole and breaks. What is the reason?</b> With regard to <i>matza</i> the phrase <b>“Bread of affliction”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3) <b>is written,</b> and the poor typically eat their bread in pieces. Therefore, eating <i>matza</i> on Passover evening, the broken <i>matza</i> is also significant.
In connection to the various <i>halakhot</i> with regard to breaking bread, especially on Festivals, the Gemara cites another <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Abba said: And on Shabbat one is obligated to break</b> bread for the meal <b>over two loaves. What is the reason?</b> Because in the Torah portion that discusses gathering manna on Friday for Shabbat, the phrase: <b>“Twice as much bread”</b> (Exodus 16:22) <b>is written.</b> To commemorate this, Shabbat meals are based on two loaves of bread.
With regard to the manner in which these two loaves are to be broken, <b>Rav Ashi said: I saw Rav Kahana who would take two</b> loaves <b>and break one. Rabbi Zeira would break</b> off one large piece from the loaf, and eat from it <b>for the entire</b> Shabbat <b>meal. Ravina said to Rav Ashi</b> about this: <b>Doesn’t it appear gluttonous</b> for one to break off so large a piece? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Since every</b> other <b>day</b> he <b>does not do so, and today he does, it does not appear gluttonous,</b> but rather in deference to the mitzva of the Shabbat meals.
With regard to eating on Shabbat, the Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ami and Rav Asi, when the</b> opportunity to use <b>the bread of the <i>eiruv</i></b> in the Shabbat meal <b>would present itself,</b> they would <b>recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth over it. They said</b> in explanation: <b>Since one mitzva was performed with it, we will perform another mitzva with it.</b>

Daf 40a

Continuing to discuss the <i>halakhot</i> of breaking bread, <b>Rav said:</b> One who broke bread, and before eating it, offered a piece to another, and said: <b>Take</b> it and <b>recite a blessing, take</b> it and <b>recite a blessing, need not recite the blessing</b> a second time, because that is considered to have been for the purpose of the blessing. If, however, he said: <b>Bring salt or bring relish, he must recite the blessing</b> a second time, as that is considered an interruption between the blessing and eating the bread. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even</b> if he said: <b>Bring salt</b> or <b>bring relish,</b> it is not considered an interruption <b>and he need not recite the blessing</b> a second time. Only if he said: <b>Mix</b> the food <b>for the oxen, mix</b> the food <b>for the oxen,</b> it is considered an interruption <b>and he is required to recite the blessing</b> a second time. <b>And Rav Sheshet said: Even</b> if he said: <b>Mix for the oxen, he need not recite a blessing</b> a second time, as that is also considered to be for the purpose of the blessing, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One is prohibited from eating before feeding his animals, as it is stated: “And I will give grass in your fields for your animals”</b> first <b>and</b> only <b>then: “And you shall eat and be satisfied”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:15). In the verse, preparation of food for one’s cattle precedes preparation of his own food. Consequently, it is considered part of the preparation for one’s own meal.
<b>Rava bar Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One who breaks</b> bread <b>is not permitted to break</b> it <b>until they bring salt or relish before each and every one</b> seated at the table. However, the Gemara relates that <b>Rava bar Shmuel</b> himself <b>happened</b> to come <b>to the House of the Exilarch. They brought him bread, which he immediately broke,</b> without waiting for them to bring salt or relish. <b>They said to him: Did the Master reconsider his halakhic</b> ruling? <b>He said to them:</b> Although poor quality bread requires salt in order to give the bread flavor, and therefore one must wait before breaking bread, <b>this</b> refined bread served in the House of the Exilarch needs no salt, and <b>does not require waiting.</b>
<b>And Rava bar Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: Urine only completely</b> leaves the body if one urinates <b>seated,</b> as, otherwise, due to concern that drops of urine will drip onto his clothes, he attempts to conclude prematurely. <b>Rav Kahana said: Over loose soil</b> which absorbs the urine, one is not concerned that it will splash on him; therefore, <b>even when standing</b> the urine leaves his body. <b>And if there is no loose soil</b> there is another way to prevent the urine from splashing on his clothes while standing. <b>Stand on an elevated place and urinate down an inclined plane.</b>
<b>And Rava bar Shmuel said</b> the following advice <b>in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: After all eating, eat salt and after all drinking, drink water and you will not be harmed. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>After all eating, eat salt and after all drinking, drink water and you will not be harmed. It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one ate any food and did not eat salt</b> afterward, or <b>if he drank any liquid and did not drink water</b> afterward, <b>during the day, he should be concerned about bad breath, and at night he should be concerned about diphtheria.</b>
On the topic of health, the Gemara cites that <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who inundates his food with water,</b> i.e., one who drinks a great deal of water, <b>will not come to suffer</b> from <b>intestinal illness.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> water? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: One jug [<i>kiton</i>] per loaf.</b>
<b>Rav Mari said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who is accustomed</b> to eat <b>lentils once in thirty days prevents diphtheria from</b> afflicting <b>his house.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>However,</b> one should <b>not</b> eat lentils <b>every day. What is the reason? Because it is deleterious</b> in that it causes <b>bad breath.</b>
<b>And Rav Mari said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who is accustomed</b> to eat <b>mustard once in thirty days prevents illnesses from</b> afflicting <b>his house.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>However,</b> one should <b>not</b> eat mustard <b>every day. What is the reason? Because it is deleterious</b> in that it causes <b>weakness of the heart.</b>
Another health recommendation: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who is accustomed</b> to eat <b>small fish will not come to suffer</b> from <b>intestinal illness. Moreover,</b> eating <b>small fish causes one’s entire body to flourish, to grow, and to be healthy.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: One who is accustomed</b> to eat <b>black cumin,</b> a medicine for the heart, <b>will not come to suffer</b> from <b>heart pain. The Gemara raises an objection: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Black cumin is one of sixty deadly drugs, and</b> therefore <b>one who sleeps to the east of its storage</b> area, where its odor wafts with the westerly wind, responsibility for <b>his blood is on his</b> own <b>head.</b> The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult, as this,</b> where Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said that black cumin is harmful, refers to <b>its odor,</b> whereas <b>this,</b> where Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said that it is beneficial for the heart, refers only to <b>its taste.</b> And the Gemara relates: <b>The mother</b> of <b>Rabbi Yirmeya would bake him bread and would stick</b> black cumin <b>to it</b> so its taste would be absorbed, <b>and she would peel it</b> off, so that its odor would not harm him.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that one recites over herbs and leafy greens: <b>Who creates various kinds of herbs. Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s</b> opinion? <b>The verse says: “Blessed is the Lord, day by day”</b> (Psalms 68:20). The question arises: <b>Is it so that one blesses Him by day and does not bless Him at night? Rather,</b> the verse comes <b>to tell you: Each and every day, give the Lord</b> the appropriate <b>blessings</b> for that day. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the blessings recited over food, for <b>each and every type</b> of food, <b>give the</b> Lord the appropriate blessings for that food.
<b>And Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: Come and see that the attribute of flesh and blood is unlike the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He. The attribute of flesh and blood is</b> that <b>an empty vessel holds</b> that which is placed within it, while <b>a full</b> vessel <b>does not hold</b> it. <b>The attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> however, <b>is not so,</b> as if God adds to a person who is <b>a full vessel</b> in terms of knowledge or good attributes, he will <b>hold</b> it; a person who is <b>an empty</b> vessel <b>will not hold</b> it. This is alluded to by the verse where <b>it is said: “And He said, if you will surely listen [<i>shamo’a tishma</i>]</b> to the voice of the Lord your God and do what is right in His eyes” (Exodus 15:26). This verse is interpreted homiletically: <b>If you listen [<i>shamo’a</i>]</b> in the present, <b>you will listen [<i>tishma</i>]</b> in the future as well; <b>and if not, you will not listen. Alternatively: If you listened [<i>shamo’a</i>] to the old,</b> you review what you already learned, then <b>you will listen [<i>tishma</i>] to the new</b> as well. But <b>if you turn your heart away, you will no longer be able to hear.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This mishna discusses how, after the fact, a more general blessing exempts one from the obligation to recite a more specific one. <b>One who recited: Who creates fruit of the ground, over fruit of the tree, fulfilled</b> his obligation. One who recited: <b>Who creates fruit of the tree, over fruits of the earth, did not fulfill</b> his obligation. <b>And over all</b> food items, <b>one who recited: By whose word all things came to be, fulfilled</b> his obligation.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara begins by ascertaining: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> that holds that <b>the primary</b> factor in the growth <b>of a tree is the earth,</b> and therefore one may recite: Who creates fruit of the ground, over fruits of the tree fulfills his obligation? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: That</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned</b> in a mishna dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of first fruits: If, after one picked the first fruits from his field, <b>the spring dried up and the tree</b> upon which the fruit grew <b>was chopped</b> down, <b>he brings</b> the first fruits to the Temple but <b>does not read</b> the accompanying praise. The tree or spring, which were the primary components of the growth of the fruit, no longer exist and he cannot recite the passage thanking God for “the good land.” <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He brings</b> the first fruits <b>and reads</b> the accompanying praise, as the land is the primary factor in the growth of the tree, and the tree itself is merely an extension of the land. Even after the tree is felled, the land remains intact. Similarly, with regard to blessings, the <i>halakha</i> maintains that fruit of the tree is considered to be fruit of the ground, as well.
We learned in the mishna: One who recited: Who creates fruit of the tree, <b>over fruits of the earth,</b> did not fulfill his obligation. The Gemara asks: <b>That is obvious,</b> as fruits of the earth do not fall under the rubric of trees. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This ruling in the mishna <b>is only necessary according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said</b> in another context that <b>wheat is a type of tree, as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The tree from which Adam, the first</b> man, <b>ate, Rabbi Meir says: It was a vine, as nothing brings wailing</b> and trouble <b>upon man</b> even today <b>other than wine,</b> as <b>it is stated</b> with regard to Noah: <b>“And he drank from the wine and became drunk”</b> (Genesis 9:21). <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: It was a fig</b> tree, <b>as with the object with which they were corrupted</b> and sinned <b>they were rehabilitated, as it is stated: “And they sewed together fig leaves</b> and made for themselves loincloths” (Genesis 3:7). They must have taken the leaves from the tree closest at hand, the Tree of Knowledge. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It was wheat, as,</b> even today, <b>the child does not know how to call</b> his <b>father and mother until he tastes the taste of grain.</b>
Based on this, <b>it might have entered your mind to say, since Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>wheat is a type of tree, one should recite over it: Who creates fruit of the tree.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>taught us</b> that with regard to blessings, the principle is different. <b>Where does one recite: Who creates fruit of the tree?</b> Only in a case <b>where, when you take the fruit, the branch remains and again produces</b> fruit.

Daf 40b

<b>However,</b> in a situation <b>where, when you take the fruit, the branch does not remain and again produce</b> fruit, <b>we do not recite the blessing: Who creates fruit of the tree, but rather: Who creates fruit of the ground.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And on all</b> food items, <b>if he recited:</b> By whose word <b>all things</b> came to be, he fulfilled his obligation. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disputed the precise explanation of the mishna. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies to all foods <b>except for bread and wine.</b> Since they have special blessings, one does not fulfill his obligation by reciting the general blessing: By whose word all things came to be. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> One fulfills his obligation with the blessing: By whose word all things came to be, <b>even</b> over <b>bread and wine.</b>
The Gemara remarks: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute is <b>parallel to a tannaitic</b> dispute found elsewhere, as it was taught in a <i>Tosefta</i>: One who <b>saw bread and said: How pleasant is this bread, blessed is the Omnipresent Who created it, fulfilled</b> his obligation to recite a blessing. <b>One who saw a fig and said: How pleasant is this fig, blessed is the Omnipresent Who created it, fulfilled</b> his obligation. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One who deviates from the formula coined by the Sages in blessings, did not fulfill his obligation.</b> If so, <b>let us say</b> that <b>Rav Huna,</b> who <b>said</b> that one who recites: By whose word all things came to be, over bread or wine, did not fulfill his obligation, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei; and Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who <b>said</b> that one who recites: By whose word all things came to be, over bread or wine fulfills his obligation, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: I said</b> my statement, <b>even</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> as <b>Rabbi Meir only stated</b> his opinion, that one who alters the formula of the blessing fulfills his obligation, <b>there, where</b> the individual explicitly <b>mentions the term bread</b> in his blessing, <b>but where he does not mention</b> the <b>term bread, even Rabbi Meir agrees</b> that he did not fulfill his obligation.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: I said</b> my statement, <b>even</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yosei only stated</b> his opinion, that one who alters the formula of the blessing does not fulfill his obligation, <b>there, because he recited a blessing that was not instituted by the Sages; however,</b> if <b>he recited: By whose word all things came to be, which was instituted by the Sages, even Rabbi Yosei agrees</b> that, after the fact, he fulfilled his obligation to recite a blessing.
Regarding blessings that do not conform to the formula instituted by the Sages, the Gemara relates that <b>Binyamin the shepherd ate bread and</b> afterward <b>recited</b> in Aramaic: <b>Blessed is the Master of this bread. Rav said,</b> he thereby <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation to recite a blessing. The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t Rav</b> himself <b>say: Any blessing that does not contain mention of God’s name is not</b> considered a <b>blessing?</b> The Gemara emends the formula of his blessing. <b>He said: Blessed is the All-Merciful, Master of this bread.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But don’t we require three blessings</b> in Grace after Meals? How did he fulfill his obligation with one sentence? The Gemara explains: <b>What is: Fulfills his obligation, that Rav also said? He fulfills</b> the obligation <b>of the first</b> of the three <b>blessings,</b> and must recite two more to fulfill his obligation completely.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Although he recited</b> the blessing <b>in a secular language,</b> other than Hebrew, he fulfilled his obligation.
This remains difficult, as <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> this in a mishna in <i>Sota</i>: <b>And these are recited in any language</b> that one understands: <b>The portion of</b> the swearing of the <b><i>sota</i>,</b> the <b>confession</b> of the <b>tithes</b> when a homeowner declares that he has given all <i>teruma</i> and tithes appropriately, <b>the recitation of <i>Shema</i>, and</b> the <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer and Grace after Meals.</b> If Grace after Meals is clearly on the list of matters that may be recited in any language, what did Rav teach us? The Gemara answers: Rav’s ruling with regard to Binyamin the Shepherd <b>is necessary, as it might have entered your mind to say: This,</b> the permission to recite Grace after Meals in any language, <b>applies only</b> to a case where one <b>recited it in a secular language, just as it was instituted by the Sages in the holy tongue. However,</b> in a case <b>where</b> one <b>did not recite</b> the blessing <b>in a secular language, just as it was instituted by the Sages in the holy tongue, say</b> that <b>no,</b> he did <b>not</b> fulfill his obligation. Therefore, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that, after the fact, not only is the language not an impediment to fulfillment of his obligation to recite a blessing, the formula is not an impediment either.
The Gemara considers <b>the matter</b> of Rav’s opinion <b>itself</b> and cites the fundamental dispute in that regard. <b>Rav said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of God’s name is not</b> considered a <b>blessing. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of</b> God’s <b>sovereignty is not</b> considered a <b>blessing. Abaye said: It stands to reason in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, as it was taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: In the confession of the tithes, one recites, <b>“I did not transgress your mitzvot and I did not forget”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:13). The meaning of phrase, <b>I did not transgress,</b> is that I did not refrain <b>from blessing You</b> when separating tithes; and the meaning of the phrase, <b>and I did not forget,</b> is that I did not forget <b>to mention Your name in</b> the blessing recited <b>over it. However, this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>did not teach</b> that one must mention God’s <b>sovereignty</b> in the blessing.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would say: <b>Emend</b> the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And I did not forget to mention Your name and Your sovereignty in</b> the blessing recited <b>over it;</b> indicating that one must mention both God’s name and God’s sovereignty.
